column3: DropwizardTestSupport should only override the app's ConfigurationSou…
column4: …rceProvider if one is explicitly provided in a constructor (#2719)  ###### Problem:  See #2719   ###### Solution:  Made `DropwizardTestSupport`s `ConfigurationSourceProvider` override nullable, and only override the app's `ConfigurationSourceProvider` if one is explicitly provided via a constructor.  ###### Result:  This will fix the behavior of `DropwizardTestSupport` in tests when the app sets a different `ConfigurationSourceProvider`.

column3: An opt-in Request Log Filter for configurable URLs
column4: Would others find it useful to have a request log filter factory they can use to configure specific URLs to filter out request logs for? I personally find this somewhat useful, if for instance my health check request logs don't provide *much* value, and it's helpful to filter out some of that noise to see real user traffic.

Would it be possible to bump jetty to 9.4.33? The current version suffers from [CVE-2020-27216](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-27216) and our build blocks releasing since we check for vulnerabilities.

[1] https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation/current/jetty-dump-tool.html#configuring-dump-feature [2] https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3132 [3] https://www.dropwizard.io/1.3.9/docs/manual/configuration.html#man-configuration-all

column3: Dropwizard hibernate: using transactional and DELAYED_ACQUISITION_AND_RELEASE_AFTER_STATEMENT in parallel requests generates the error "Cannot commit when autoCommit is enabled."
column4: When we have `DELAYED_ACQUISITION_AND_RELEASE_AFTER_STATEMENT` in our handling mode configuration and we try to use a resource with `transactional = true`, if we make two parallel calls to this service we take the error "Cannot commit when `autoCommit` is enabled."  Can't use `DELAYED_ACQUISITION_AND_RELEASE_AFTER_STATEMENT` and have a resource with `transactional = true`? Or It's a bug?  Sample code:  ```java @Path("/test") public class TestTransactionalWithAfterStatement {  	private PersonDAO dao; 	 	public TestTransactionalWithAfterStatement(PersonDAO dao) { 		this.dao = dao; 	} 	 	@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON) 	@GET     @Timed     @UnitOfWork     @Path("/{id}/name/{name}")     public Long sayHello(@PathParam("id") int id, @PathParam("name") String name) throws InterruptedException { 		Person person = new Person(id, name); 		long number = dao.create(person); 		Thread.sleep(10000); 		return number;     } 	 } ```  Hibernate config:  ``` properties:     charSet: UTF-8     hibernate.dialect: org.hibernate.dialect.PostgreSQLDialect     hibernate.jdbc.fetch_size: 1000     hibernate.jdbc.batch_size: 30     hibernate.connection.autocommit: false     hibernate.connection.isolation: java.sql.Connection.TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED     hibernate.temp.use_jdbc_metadata_defaults: false     hibernate.connection.handling_mode: DELAYED_ACQUISITION_AND_RELEASE_AFTER_STATEMENT ```  If we switch to `DELAYED_ACQUISITION_AND_RELEASE_AFTER_TRANSACTION` then it works...

column3: Documentation: Task execute method has changed
column4: When upgrading from 1.3 to 2.0.9, I've noticed that the execute method signature has slightly changed to `execute(Map parameters, PrintWriter output)`, but this is not mentioned in the migration guide, nor in the manual https://www.dropwizard.io/en/latest/manual/core.html#tasks

column3: DropwizardExtensionsSupport does not work correctly with nested tests
column4: When test class annotated with DropwizardExtensionsSupport contains inner classes annotated with Nested then DropwizardExtensions in outer class are not initialized when running nested tests.  ``` @ExtendWith(DropwizardExtensionsSupport.class) public class ResourceTest {      private ResourceExtension resources = ResourceExtension.builder().build();      @Test     void outerTest() {         resources.target("");     }      @Nested     class InnerResourceTest{         @Test         void innerTest() {             resources.target("");         }     } } ``` In the example above outerTest is successful but innerTest fails with following exception: ``` java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.util.Objects.requireNonNull(Objects.java:203) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.common.Resource.getJerseyTest(Resource.java:179) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.common.Resource.target(Resource.java:159) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.junit5.ResourceExtension.target(ResourceExtension.java:65) ``` I guess as a solution DropwizardExtensionsSupport should be modified. When finding test class members, should also check if test class has enclosing class and look for its members also.

When running the [FreemarkerViewRenderer](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-views-freemarker/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/views/freemarker/FreemarkerViewRenderer.java) several error messages are logged from freemarker:  ``` [2020-03-16T16:42:03,118Z](dw-admin-47)([]) ERROR - configuration - DefaultObjectWrapper.incompatibleImprovements was set to the object returned by Configuration.getVersion(). That defeats the purpose of incompatibleImprovements, and makes upgrading FreeMarker a potentially breaking change. Also, this probably won't be allowed starting from 2.4.0. Instead, set incompatibleImprovements to the highest concrete version that's known to be compatible with your application. [2020-03-16T16:42:03,119Z](dw-admin-47)([]) ERROR - configuration - Configuration.incompatibleImprovements was set to the object returned by Configuration.getVersion(). That defeats the purpose of incompatibleImprovements, and makes upgrading FreeMarker a potentially breaking change. Also, this probably won't be allowed starting from 2.4.0. Instead, set incompatibleImprovements to the highest concrete version that's known to be compatible with your application. [2020-03-16T16:42:03,119Z](dw-admin-47)([]) ERROR - configuration - DefaultObjectWrapper.incompatibleImprovements was set to the object returned by Configuration.getVersion(). That defeats the purpose of incompatibleImprovements, and makes upgrading FreeMarker a potentially breaking change. Also, this probably won't be allowed starting from 2.4.0. Instead, set incompatibleImprovements to the highest concrete version that's known to be compatible with your application. ```  This appears to be due to setting the freemarker `Configuration` object to `Configuration.getVersion()`: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-views-freemarker/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/views/freemarker/FreemarkerViewRenderer.java#L38  The error log introduced in freemarker can be found [here](https://github.com/apache/freemarker/commit/e816f81e55d9cd00b7c17525fd665eff1f630bb2) and mentions the bad pattern: ``` new Configuration(Configuration.getVersion()); ```

column3: Jackson Afterburner causes JVM warnings on Java 9 and beyond
column4: When creating ObjectMapper instances with the `Jackson.newObjectMapper` method the Jackson’s Afterburner module is  registered causing the following JVM warning:  ``` WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred WARNING: Illegal reflective access by com.fasterxml.jackson.module.afterburner.util.MyClassLoader (file:.m2/repository/com/fasterxml/jackson/module/jackson-module-afterburner/2.9.9/jackson-module-afterburner-2.9.9.jar) to method java.lang.ClassLoader.findLoadedClass(java.lang.String) WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of com.fasterxml.jackson.module.afterburner.util.MyClassLoader WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release ```  Please see more detailed information here: https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-modules-base/issues/37  It would be good to have an option in Dropwizard to disable the Afterburner module, or configure it not `setUseValueClassLoader(false)`, or use alternative Jackson Blackbird module https://github.com/stevenschlansker/jackson-blackbird.  One possible solution I can think of is to add a JackonModuleConfigService service provider interface which would return the Jackson module instances being registered, so the application can disable or reconfigure each individual module.

column3: Logger level of OFF results in "Unsupported format of logger"
column4: When configuring a logger level of `OFF` via "logging -> loggers" using the simple form of `com.example.my.logger: OFF`, fails with "Unsupported format of logger".  This is a corner case because the yaml parsing converts `OFF` to `false` and the simple level config is only expecting a String/textual value. The other level parsing in `DefaultLoggingFactory` use `toLevel()` to handle this case.   A workaround is to quote the level: `com.example.my.logger: "OFF"`   PR with a fix to follow.

What would be a secure email alias to report a security issue?  Note: would be a nice to set a [security policy](https://help.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/adding-a-security-policy-to-your-repository)

column3: DualSessionFactory: feature request enhancement to the dropwizard-hibernate module
column4: We've built an extension to the dropwizard-hiberbate module that manages both a writer SessionFactory and a reader SessionFactory within a single DualSessionFactory object. The DualSessionFactory piggybacks off the UnitOfWork annotation to determine which SessionFactory is used for each RESTful call. When "readOnly=true" is specified for a call, the reader SessionFactory will be substituted in place of the default/primary/writer SessionFactory.  To implement, we've extended the HibernateBundle and cloned with minor changes the UnitOfWorkApplicationListener & UnitOfWorkAspect classes. We've also add the DualSessionFactory class which implements the org.hibernate.SessionFactory interface by delegating to either the primary SessionFactory or the reader SessionFactory.  The integration of the DualSessionFactory has dramatically lowered our calls to the primary Aurora instance in favor of the read-replica cluster. That alone has breathed additional life into the scalability of transactional data source.  If you would like for us to proceed, please instruct us on the next steps.  Best regards, smalleyd

column3: Slightly more memory is used for 2.0.x
column4: We've [recently upgraded from dropwizard 1.3.12 to 2.0.8](https://github.com/graphhopper/graphhopper/pull/1998) and observed that it uses 10-20MB more memory than before. I.e. our test were happy with "-Xmx100m" and now require at least "-Xmx110m" to avoid a frequent failure. It seems to be like a small thing, but when you just compare the "framework overhead" then this increase is substantial.  Is this expected? If not, I can try to create a reproducer with some hello world sample.

We're using dropwizard 1.0.5 and we're getting an intermittent NPE. We're using postgresql. I am curious if this has been found or resolved in another version. Since it is intermittent, it's hard to test later versions for the same problem. Any insight would be helpful.  Method Signature `@SqlQuery(MATCH_FETCH_ALL + " OFFSET :offset LIMIT :limit") Collection getMatches( @Bind("id") final Integer id, @Bind("offset") final Integer offset, @Bind("limit") final Integer limit);`  `ERROR [0&limit=10] [ggingExceptionMapper] - Error handling a request: dee1473ed0fd2500 java.lang.NullPointerException: null ---> at io.dropwizard.jdbi.NamePrependingStatementRewriter.rewrite(NamePrependingStatementRewriter.java:18) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.SQLStatement.internalExecute(SQLStatement.java:1296) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.Query.fold(Query.java:173) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.Query.list(Query.java:82) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.ResultReturnThing$IterableReturningThing.result(ResultReturnThing.java:253) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.ResultReturnThing.map(ResultReturnThing.java:46) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.QueryHandler.invoke(QueryHandler.java:43) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.SqlObject.invoke(SqlObject.java:212) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.SqlObject$3.intercept(SqlObject.java:127) --->at org.skife.jdbi.v2.sqlobject.CloseInternalDoNotUseThisClass$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$f5b2410c.getMatches() --->at MatchService.getMatches(MatchService.java:420)`

column3: Allow option to report metrics on stopping dropwizard
column4: We use dropwizard extensively and are fans of how relatively quick it starts and stops.  When testing locally, we start our application from its all-in-one jar file and shut it down again after the tests, configuring metrics as local .csv files. However, we never see them :disappointed:  This is because dropwizard starts, we run tests and dropwizard stops again without ever getting the `report()` called from `ScheduledReporterManager` .  For us, it would be great if we could configure a `reportOnStop` setting to `true` that would cause one last `report()` when stopping. We have no problems defaulting this to `false` to remain backward-compatible.  I will submit a pull request for this myself. Thanks!

We haven't been checking the Checkstyle reports for a long time and haven't been fixing any violations, so it's safe to say we don't really need or care for using Checkstyle in Dropwizard. 😉  This should at least save a little time during builds.

column3: db migrate does not use specified schema for liquibase tables
column4: We have a setup with two Postgres users (**test_app** and **test_admin**) in a database (**test**). When running **db migrate** liquibase insists on creating it's two tables in non-existent schema **test_admin** and migration fails. I have tried specifying **--schema** on the command line and apending to the jdbc string: ` bin/server db migrate config_min.yml --schema test jdbc:postgresql://db/test?currentSchema=test `  Each user has search path set to just **test** schema, public schema droppped.  As a temporary workaround we have created the extra **test_admin** schema to keep liquibase happy. Not sure whether this is a bug or a feature missing.  P.S Using Dropwizard 2.0.0

column3: Dropwizard REST API JSON response chopped off
column4: We have a set of microservices, and we use dropwizard(v1.3.1). All the POST requests are working without any problem, but the GET API's response is partially chopped off. In the dropwizard documentation, and in some of the similar issues reported, the suggested solution was to disable gzip. We disabled gzip:  ``` server:    gzip:       enabled: false ``` This doesn't seem to have any effect. Interestingly, this doesn't happen in the local(Mac OSX). We use AWS infrastructure for DEV. The response is in JSON format.  The response header: ``` Content-Encoding →UTF-8 Content-Encoding →gzip ``` The actual content length is 532 bytes, but the response content-length shows 305 bytes.  Edit: This is happening only with a GET API. When I changed it to POST, content is completely displayed.

column3: JUnit 5 test with HttpSession fails with DropwizardExtensionsSupport
column4: We came across a scenario where we wanted to write a unit test for `@Session HttpSession session` being injected into a resource.  We were trying to mimic the behavior of DockerIntegrationTest.java which is included with dropwizard-example project. You can mimic the failure by simply adding `@Session HttpSession session` to `HelloWorldResource` and re-running the test.  It was obvious if this was a limitation in the underlying test container being used here or if there was a way to enable session support in a test.  Here's the output of the error: ``` ERROR [2020-06-19 21:41:38,961] io.dropwizard.jersey.errors.IllegalStateExceptionMapper: Error handling a request: 77e5c65c7de94fa7 ! java.lang.IllegalStateException: No SessionManager ! column3: Issue with UnitOfWork and WebTargets in UnitTests in Kotlin
column4: We are currently trying our first dropwizard application in Kotlin. Everything works fine except the UnitOfWork annotation.  We have the following little endpoint that works perfectly fine if you call it with a simple ApiClient like Postman:  ```kotlin     @GET     @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)     @Timed     @UnitOfWork     fun getAttributes(@Auth user: User): CoreAttributes {         return CoreAttributes(userDao.getUser(user.id) ?: throw NotFoundException())     } ```  The problem here is userDAO.getUser(user.id). The DAO looks like this:  ```kotlin open class UserDAO @Inject constructor(sessionFactory: SessionFactory): AbstractDAO(sessionFactory) {      fun getUser(id: Long): UserData? {         return get(id)     } } ```  So in getUser(id: Long) the get method of the AbstractDAO in io.dropwizard.hibernate is called. That is basically this function:  ```java     protected E get(Serializable id) {         return (E) currentSession().get(entityClass, requireNonNull(id));     } ```      And the problem is that currentSession() throws org.hibernate.HibernateException: No session currently bound to execution context We call the endpoint like this in our unit tests:  ```kotlin     val webTarget: WebTarget = target("the-endpoint-url").request().get() ```      Calling the endpoint with an api client works. But calling the endpoint like this in our unit tests does not work. We did the same thing in our java services and in java it works perfectly fine.  Any ideas about that? I read something that Kotlin may have problems with reflaction operation in java frameworks or libraries but I'm not sure if reflection is the case here.  Thanks in advance!

ProtectedResource()); ```  ``` WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred WARNING: Illegal reflective access by javassist.util.proxy.SecurityActions (file:/Users/username/.m2/repository/org/javassist/javassist/3.25.0-GA/javassist-3.25.0-GA.jar) to method java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(java.lang.String,byte[],int,int,java.security.ProtectionDomain) WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of javassist.util.proxy.SecurityActions WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release ```   If I run with the `--illegal-access=deny` option configured, then I receive the following error:  ``` java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.reflect.InaccessibleObjectException: Unable to make protected final Using Dropwizard 1.3.17, we retrieve the ServiceLocator as such: ```java ServiceLocator serviceLocator = ((ServletContainer) environment.getJerseyServletContainer()).getApplicationHandler().getServiceLocator(); ``` When we migrated to Dropwizard 2, this became: ```java ServletContainer servletContainer = (ServletContainer) Objects.requireNonNull(environment.getJerseyServletContainer()); ApplicationHandler applicationHandler = servletContainer.getApplicationHandler(); InjectionManager injectionManager = applicationHandler.getInjectionManager(); ServiceLocator serviceLocator; if (injectionManager instanceof ImmediateHk2InjectionManager) {   serviceLocator = ((ImmediateHk2InjectionManager) injectionManager).getServiceLocator(); } else if (injectionManager instanceof DelayedHk2InjectionManager) {   serviceLocator = ((DelayedHk2InjectionManager) injectionManager).getServiceLocator(); } else {   throw new IllegalStateException("Expecting an HK2 injection manager"); } ``` However, ApplicationHandler is null. Any ideas?

Using a "reserved" package, such as `ch.qos.logback.core.recovery` from Logback, in an unrelated artifact will cause problems with the Java Platform Module System (JPMS).  In order to prevent a future conflict, the `ResilientSocketOutputStream` and the parent class `ResilientOutputStreamBase` from Logback have been moved into `io.dropwizard.logging`.  While copying code is usually a bad idea, I don't see how we could support Java 9+ with Dropwizard without this change or a change from the Logback project to change the modifier of the required methods in `ResilientOutputStreamBase` to `protected`.  Fixes #2312

column3: Support for system property in configured command
column4: Update to give the opportunity to inform the path of the configuration file via system property. If no file path program argument is provided try to lookup to the system property key based on application's name to get the file path.  ###### Problem: There is no possibility of getting the path to the configuration file through system property.  ###### Solution: Before attempting to parse the configuration file, try to get the path via system property if no path has been informed via program argument. The key to get the path is based on the name of the application.  e.g:  ```java public class TempApp extends Application {     @Override     public String getName() {         return "Temp App";     } } ```  When the ConfiguredCommand#run(Bootstrap, Namespace) is invoked the application's name will be parsed to create the key to lookup in the system property for the configuration path (temp.app.configurationFile).  ###### Result: With this change, now the configuration path can be informed via program argument or via vm options -Dtemp.app.configurationFile=...

column3: Executor metrics shouldn't contain fmt string.
column4: Update ExecutorServiceBuilder to remove the format string from the metric name. Currently, a thread pool named 'jersey-client-foo-%d' will have metrics 'jersey-client-foo-%d.created', 'jersey-client-foo-%d.terminated', and 'jersey-client-foo-%d.running' added to the metrics registry. The '-%d' format string is only meant to ensure that threads are uniquely named and shouldn't be included in the name of the metric.  Update ExecutorServiceBuilder to strip the format portion of the nameFormat from the metric name.  Fixes #3139.

Update dropwizard to run maven-dependency-plugin analyze-only goal as part of the build. This will automate detection of new dependencies as well as when dependencies are no longer in use. In some cases there may be some false positives (seen primarily when only using an import from a dependency), however overall this should improve the quality of the POM files for dropwizard.

column3: Update jackson.version to 2.9.10 to address CVE-2019-14540 & CVE-2019-16335
column4: Update `jackson.version` in `dropwizard-bom` from 2.9.9.20190807 to 2.9.10  This addresses two CVE, both with CVSS v3.1 score of 9.8 * [CVE-2019-14540](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-14540) * [CVE-2019-16335](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-16335)  The update should be done for both release/1.3.x branch and for master (2.0.x)

column3: Update jackson.version to 2.9.10.20191020 to address CVE
column4: Update `jackson.version` in `dropwizard-bom` from 2.9.10 to 2.9.10.20191020  This updates jackson-databind from 2.9.10 to 2.9.10.1, and addresses three CVE, all with CVSS v3.1 score of 9.8 * [CVE-2019-16942](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-16942) * [CVE-2019-16943](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-16943) * [CVE-2019-17531](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-17531)	  The update should be done release/1.3.x branch. Master (2.0.x) is using jackson 2.10.0 which is not vulnerable to the CVE.

column3: Update jackson version to 2.9.10.20200103 in 1.3.x branch
column4: Update `jackson.version` from 2.9.10.20191020 to 2.9.10.20200103 This has effect of updating `jackson-databind` from 2.9.10.1 to 2.9.10.2 and addresses [CVE-2019-20330](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-20330)  ###### Problem: Dropwizard 1.3.17 uses `jackson-databind` 2.9.10.1.  This is vulnerable to CVE-2019-20330  ###### Solution: Update `jackson.version` in `dropwizard-bom` from 2.9.10.20191020 to 2.9.10.20200103.  ###### Result: Updating `jackson.version` results in update to `jackson-bom` that is imported by Dropwizard 1.3.x., thus updating `jackson-databind` from 2.9.10.1 to 2.9.10.2. From [jackson release notes](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson/wiki/Jackson-Release-2.9):  > jackson-databind 2.9.10.2 (03-Jan-2020) > 2526: Block two more gadget types (ehcache/JNDI -CVE-2019-20330) > 2544: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError Thrown for compact profile1  Note that PR is only necessary for Dropwizard 1.3.x branch.  Dropwizard 2.x uses jackson 2.10.x and is not vulnerable to the CVE.

tomcat jdbc allows validationQuery to be null, see https://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-9.0-doc/jdbc-pool.html . In that case it will validate connections by isValid() method on Connection object.  In our company, we get our database logs flooded by SELECT 1 queries, causing not being able to hold more than one day of logs. This is caused by setting up checkConnectionWhileIdle and other connection checks (which we want to keep) and the fact that in dropwizard it is not possible to set validationQuery to null. This setting, causing the call to isValid(), would help for drivers which implement this method by not executing the query.  I would happily help with implementation of this.

column3: 2.0.0 regression: @UriInfo always returns http as scheme
column4: This used to work in 1.3.x, but no longer seems to work in 2.0.0-rc12:  ``` public class TestApplication extends Application {     @Override     public void run(Configuration configuration, Environment environment) throws Exception {         environment.jersey().register(TestResource.class);     }      public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {         new TestApplication().run(args);     }      @Path("/")     public static class TestResource {         @GET         public String printUriInfoScheme(@Context UriInfo uriInfo) {             return uriInfo.getBaseUri().getScheme();         }     } } ```  Always returns "http", even if called using a https URL (e.g. using ngrok).

column3: registerDefaultExceptionMappers is not a JSON Property and there is not way to reconfig it
column4: This should be expose as JSON property so that default/simple could configure it.  https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/82e62e9c91b5acb3a47c04783f1204fc2aed34be/dropwizard-core/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/server/AbstractServerFactory.java#L445

column3: The JUnit5 example described in java doc of DropwizardAppExtension doesn't actually work
column4: This section in the java docs describing using a single Application instance to run all your tests: ``` Using DropwizardAppExtension at the suite level can speed up test runs, as the application is only started and stopped once for the entire suite:   public class MySuite {    public static final DropwizardAppExtension DROPWIZARD = new DropwizardAppExtension(...);  }   If the same instance of DropwizardAppExtension is reused at the suite- and class-level, then the application will be started and stopped once, regardless of whether the entire suite or a single test is executed.   @ExtendWith(DropwizardExtensionsSupport.class)  public class FooTest {    public static final DropwizardAppExtension DROPWIZARD = MySuite.DROPWIZARD;     public void testFoo() { ... }  }   @ExtendWith(DropwizardExtensionsSupport.class)  public class BarTest {    public static final DropwizardAppExtension DROPWIZARD = MySuite.DROPWIZARD;     public void testBar() { ... }  } ``` This doesn't actually work for any subsequent tests using the client() method. client() will return the previously closed client and not open a new one. I have a PR that can fix this behavior by setting the client instance to null after it's closed, but what's happening still isn't what's described in the java doc.  Every time the after() method is called DropwizardTestSupport stops the application, and the subsequent call to before() will start a new instance of the application. You're better off just not using the extension and manually starting the app (I'm not sure if there are any negative effects  from not calling shutdown explicitly when tests complete, but there is a listener interface that could allow you to manually call after() if that's important).
This reverts commit f0efc522d1f83454bd9451b4fb7e2a851504ca92. Refs #3383
This reverts commit 6d4e4d17b1b3ffb1b0ae8e5224e84dae7538d8eb. Refs #3385

column3: Upgrade Jersey to 2.28, Hibernate validator to 6.0.14.Final
column4: This PR first thought was to upgrade Jersey version to 2.28 only. But then I found that Jersey 2.28 is using Hibernate Validator 6.x, and conflicts were found by maven dependencies enforcer.  So I went on upgrading hibernate validator to 6.0.14.Final, make all changes to make the code to compile and the tests to pass. I'm aware of the PR @joschi opened ( https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/2613 ). I'm sure his solution is better than mine in some areas. Mine does not contain yet a solution for the depreciation of JerseyParameterNameProvider base class. Yet, **I didn't have to ignore any test**. They all pass. So I'll appreciate if you can review my solution, even if not to merge it - just to help me understand my mistakes if any, and take the good part of it ;-) Thanks a lot, Uziel

column3: Add automatic module names for all Dropwizard modules
column4: This PR adds automatic module names for all Dropwizard modules.  We'll need more tests to see, if everything works with Java 9+ when using the module path.  See also: https://blog.joda.org/2018/03/jpms-negative-benefits.html  Refs https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/3233

column3: Enable Jackson Afterburner only on Java 8 (backport)
column4: This MR is to backport the fixes made on b1c39570ef51e0c337f6cacea159fbd80fb598ce to release/1.3.x  ###### Problem: The Jackson Afterburner module is currently not compatible with the JPMS and will lead to illegal reflective access operation warnings: ``` WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred WARNING: Illegal reflective access by com.fasterxml.jackson.module.afterburner.util.MyClassLoader (file:.m2/repository/com/fasterxml/jackson/module/jackson-module-afterburner/2.9.9/jackson-module-afterburner-2.9.9.jar) to method java.lang.ClassLoader.findLoadedClass(java.lang.String) WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of com.fasterxml.jackson.module.afterburner.util.MyClassLoader WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release ```  Fixes #2909 Refs #2966 Refs FasterXML/jackson-modules-base#37  ###### Solution: Cherry-pick the commit into the release/1.3.x branch to be included on the next release  ###### Result: This will allow the fix to be used on a stable version of dropwizard. As of now, the fix is only available through the 2.0 Release candidate

column3: Request log async logging appender worker threads not stopped
column4: This is the same issue as seen in  https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/1994  But somehow got closed.  Long story short I'm using a testing helper which detects leaked threads and it seems the logging thread is not stopped correctly:    ``` 1 thread leaked from SUITE scope at com.kalasearch.restful.dropwizard.MyTEst:     1) Thread[id=22, name=AsyncAppender-Worker-async-console-appender, state=WAITING, group=TGRP-MyTEst]         at java.base@11.0.5/jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:194)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.await(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2081)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.ArrayBlockingQueue.take(ArrayBlockingQueue.java:417)         at app//ch.qos.logback.core.AsyncAppenderBase$Worker.run(AsyncAppenderBase.java:289) com.carrotsearch.randomizedtesting.ThreadLeakError: 1 thread leaked from SUITE scope at com.kalasearch.restful.dropwizard.MyTEst:     1) Thread[id=22, name=AsyncAppender-Worker-async-console-appender, state=WAITING, group=TGRP-MyTEst]         at java.base@11.0.5/jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:194)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.await(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2081)         at java.base@11.0.5/java.util.concurrent.ArrayBlockingQueue.take(ArrayBlockingQueue.java:417)         at app//ch.qos.logback.core.AsyncAppenderBase$Worker.run(AsyncAppenderBase.java:289) 	at __randomizedtesting.SeedInfo.seed([A1098A089DAFEB54]:0) ```

This is more of a question than a bug...  I try to set up tests for JDBI3 DAO  without Hibernate (I use JDBI3 directly in my app)  I use testcontainers Postgres, I then set all the JDBI plugins and dependencies and use the container url to connect the JDBI and create an instance.  ```java  @Testcontainers class DaoTest {   @Container   private static final PostgreSQLContainer DATABASE =           new PostgreSQLContainer("postgres:12-alpine");   @BeforeAll   static void beforeAll() throws Exception {     Connection connection = DATABASE.createConnection("");     migrate(connection); // Liquibase migration     jdbi = Jdbi.create(connection);     setup(jdbi); // add all the plugins and Jackson marshaller   }  ```  I am getting random results, sometimes tests fail and sometimes they pass.  If I run application tests (full DW) all is working fine, so I guess my issue is the DAO test setup and not the DAO code.  Is there a test extension for this use case? Is there an example of this use case?
This is a "backport" of #2839 for `1.3.x`.

This is **not a dropwizard issue**, but I'm sure many will face this with the new 2.0.3 release.  In my case, gradle build failed like this:  ``` > Could not resolve all files for configuration ':pmd'.    > Could not find org.ow2.asm:asm:${asm.version}.      Required by:          project : > net.sourceforge.pmd:pmd-java:6.21.0 ```  This is hk2 issue: `dropwizard-dependencies` now (since 2.0.3) include [hk2-bom](https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/glassfish-hk2/blob/master/bom/pom.xml), which does not declare `asm.version` property, but declares dependencies with it.   HK2 related issue is: https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/glassfish-hk2/issues/470  The workaround is obviously to declare `asm.version` to `7.2`.  In case of gradle, for spring dependency-management plugin it would look like:  ```groovy dependencyManagement {     imports {         mavenBom ("io.dropwizard:dropwizard-dependencies:2.0.3") {             bomProperty 'asm.version', '7.2'         }     } ```

This happens on DW v: 2.0.9  When using a @BeanParam object with an OptionalDouble field in it. If the value is not sent in the request the following error is produced.   It seems to me that the possibility of a null value is being overseen here.   ``` Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.base/jdk.internal.math.FloatingDecimal.readJavaFormatString(FloatingDecimal.java:1838) 	at java.base/jdk.internal.math.FloatingDecimal.parseDouble(FloatingDecimal.java:110) 	at java.base/java.lang.Double.parseDouble(Double.java:549) 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.optional.OptionalDoubleParamConverterProvider$OptionalDoubleParamConverter.fromString(OptionalDoubleParamConverterProvider.java:50) 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.optional.OptionalDoubleParamConverterProvider$OptionalDoubleParamConverter.fromString(OptionalDoubleParamConverterProvider.java:32) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.internal.inject.AbstractParamValueExtractor.convert(AbstractParamValueExtractor.java:116) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.internal.inject.AbstractParamValueExtractor.fromString(AbstractParamValueExtractor.java:107) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.internal.inject.SingleValueExtractor.extract(SingleValueExtractor.java:61) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.server.internal.inject.QueryParamValueParamProvider$QueryParamValueProvider.apply(QueryParamValueParamProvider.java:78) ```

column3: Runtime Error on version 2.0.0 and Java 11
column4: This code seems to work fine on Dropwizard 2.0.0 and Java 8, but when I compile and run on Java 11, I get an exception when starting up.  ```java public void run(ThunderConfiguration config, Environment env) {     ThunderComponent component = DaggerThunderComponent.builder()         .daoModule(new DaoModule(config.getDynamoConfiguration().getTableName()))         .dynamoDbModule(new DynamoDbModule(config.getDynamoConfiguration()))         .emailModule(new EmailModule(config.getEmailConfiguration()))         .thunderModule(new ThunderModule(env.metrics(), config))         .build();      // Authentication     env.jersey().register(new AuthDynamicFeature(new BasicCredentialAuthFilter.Builder()             .setAuthenticator(component.getThunderAuthenticator())             .setRealm("THUNDER - AUTHENTICATION")             .buildAuthFilter()));      env.jersey().register(new AuthValueFactoryProvider.Binder(Key.class));      // HealthChecks     env.healthChecks().register("DynamoDB", component.getDynamoDbHealthCheck());      // Resources     env.jersey().register(component.getUserResource());      // Only register verification resource if it is enabled     if (config.getEmailConfiguration().isEnabled()) {       env.jersey().register(component.getVerificationResource());     }   } ```  Exception:  ``` java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: 'java.lang.Class javassist.CtClass.toClass(java.lang.Class)' 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig.register(DropwizardResourceConfig.java:170) 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.setup.JerseyEnvironment.register(JerseyEnvironment.java:36) 	at com.sanctionco.thunder.ThunderApplication.run(ThunderApplication.java:64) 	at com.sanctionco.thunder.ThunderApplication.run(ThunderApplication.java:27) 	at io.dropwizard.cli.EnvironmentCommand.run(EnvironmentCommand.java:44) 	at io.dropwizard.cli.ConfiguredCommand.run(ConfiguredCommand.java:87) 	at io.dropwizard.cli.Cli.run(Cli.java:79) 	at io.dropwizard.Application.run(Application.java:94) 	at com.sanctionco.thunder.ThunderApplication.main(ThunderApplication.java:30) ```  It looks like it's failing at `env.jersey().register(component.getUserResource());`. How should this be changed in order to work? I can't seem to find much info in the docs. Thanks in advance!

This class utilizes the DefaultLoggingFactory. Unfortunately that class affects the static logging state of the JVM. This test now forces a full reset of the logging state in any test that touches a default logging factory object.  ###### Problem: Please refer to #2550 as this does an excellent job of describing the issue as well as how to reliably reproduce it and one possible solution.  ###### Solution: I have forced a full state reset in the logging factory used by the unit test.  ###### Result: The intermittent failures due to this issue will stop (as well as the reproduction steps will no longer trigger a failure).

column3: Add config settings for tasks and health check resources
column4: This change set adds configuration settings for the tasks resource and the health check resources in the Dropwizard admin interface.  The `printStackTraceOnError` (default: false) setting allows to control whether to expose the full exception stack trace of a failing task.  The `minThreads`, `maxThreads`, and `workQueueSize` configuration settings allow to control the thread settings for health checks.  Closes #3036

This allows exception to be handled and logged.  ###### Problem: `io.dropwizard.Application` doesn't throw exceptions so they can't be caught and logged.  Its very important to know why the app crashed but nothing shows-up in the logs if you call `System.exit()` bypassing all catch blocks.  Overriding `onFatalError()` doesn't work because `onFatalError()` doesn't provide the error message.  ###### Solution: Users can catch and Exceptions and call System.exit() if they like that behavior.  ###### Result: Exceptions can be caught

column3: Remove most mentions of Guava from documentation

There is a vulnerability issue in dropwizard version - 1.3.17  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52689846/72719706-59760600-3b9e-11ea-9860-2fe470e76264.png)

There are two non-obvious limitations in the appender configuration:  1) When using the **layout** option to set a custom `LayoutFactory`, the **logFormat** is always ignored. I think it would be more consistent to apply the **logFormat** to all layouts that derive from `PatternLayoutBase` and otherwise emit a warning if both options are set. That is, changing `AbstractAppenderFactory.buildLayout()` to something like  ```java         if (layout == null) {             layoutBase = defaultLayoutFactory.build(context, timeZone);         } else {             layoutBase = layout.build(context, timeZone);         }         if (!Strings.isNullOrEmpty(logFormat)) {             if (layoutBase instanceof PatternLayoutBase) {                 ((PatternLayoutBase)layoutBase).setPattern(logFormat);             } else {                 LOGGER.warn("Ignoring 'logFormat', because 'layout' does not extend PatternLayoutBase");             }         } ```  2) When setting a **logFormat** that includes time zone information (like the default `LogbackAccessRequestLayout`), the time zone is a fixed part of the string and may contradict the configured **timeZone** option. Maybe the **logFormat** could contain some kind of placeholder (e.g. ``) that gets automatically replaced with the correct value from the **timeZone** option?

The purpose of this PR are threefold:  * *Create properties for all dependencies*: Allow overriding the version of every dependency of Dropwizard by setting a Maven property * *Split BOM into Dropwizard modules and dependencies*: The bill of materials for all Dropwizard dependendencies is now named `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-dependencies` and `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-bom` manages the version of all Dropwizard modules, but no other dependencies (refs #2880) * *Introduce dropwizard-project for common build configuration*: `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-parent` is still the parent POM for most Dropwizard modules, but automatically includes the dependencies from `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-bom` and `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-dependencies`. The `io.dropwizard:docs` module inherits from `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-project` but doesn't have any overlap with any of the Dropwizard modules carrying code.  TODO:  * [x] Document changes with regards to `io.dropwizard:dropwizard-bom` in the Dropwizard 2.0.x migration guide

column3: Command line argument not working without configuration entry
column4: The PR #866 does not seem to fix #636 (tried dropwizard version 1.3.12) and also other people seem to have this issue. I.e. you have to specify a config.yml with at least:  ``` server:   applicationConnectors:    - type: http ```  in order to change the port. Otherwise you'll get:  ``` IllegalArgumentException: Unable to override server.applicationConnectors[0].type; node with index not found ```  Sorry have reposted here [again](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/636#issuecomment-579227758) after 2 weeks, to avoid that this problem disappears in the closed issue.

column3: Remove OWASP dependency check plugin because of false positives
column4: The OWASP dependency check plugin causes a lot of false positives when building or using Dropwizard.  Dependency updates are applied in a timely manner via manual updates or Dependabot, so that the check isn't necessary.

column3: Issue with newest version of JDBI (v3.6.0)
column4: The latest version of Dropwizard (v1.3.9) is incompatible with the newest version of JDBI (v3.6.0).  The issue is related to the removal of JdbiSteams from JDBI core which Dropwizard still relies on.  Rolling back to JDBI v3.5.0 fixes the issue.  Hopefully the next Dropwizard release will resolve this.

I've already opened an [issue](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard-jdbi/issues/1) in its repository, but fear it has gone unnoticed... ?

column3: Implementation of runtime/build time compilation to Jetty handler code
column4: The idea is from here: https://github.com/noboomu/proteus `Proteus rewrites your controller methods into high performance Undertow response handlers at run time.` The same thing should be possible to be implemented for Jetty handlers.  ## What? Basically the project is translating the JAX-RS annotated methods to Java code when the application is started. There is an example project: https://github.com/noboomu/proteus-example/  ## Why? On of the committers of this project (`dropwizard`) has a blog were he explored the performance impact of Jersey. And it was significant. The post is here: https://nbsoftsolutions.com/blog/turning-dropwizard-performance-up-to-eleven  ## Drawbacks? No dynamic endpoint creation. Probably problems with the DI (dependency injection) framework integrations. Probably a lot of other things that I can't point out currently.

The hk2-bom includes dependencies on asm but doesn't define the version of artifacts to pull in. Instead of using hk2-bom, switch to pulling in specific hk2 dependencies at the proper version in the dropwizard-dependencies pom.  Fixes #3212.

column3: Context injection not working as expected in DW 2.0.0-rc1
column4: The following code works with __DW 1.3.9__ (_UriInfo_ and _CloseableService_ are properly injected), but fails with __DW  2.0.0-rc1__ (both fields are _null_ at runtime)  ```java import org.glassfish.jersey.server.CloseableService; import javax.ws.rs.*; import javax.ws.rs.core.*;  @Path("/upload") public class UploadResource {      @Context     UriInfo requestUri;      @Context     CloseableService closer; ```  Is this expected behaviour in the 2.0 release?  p.s.: I use JUnit4 and the deprecated DropwizardAppRule for setting up test resources  ```java @ClassRule     public static final DropwizardAppRule RULE =             new DropwizardAppRule(UploadServiceApplication.class, ResourceHelpers.resourceFilePath("uploadservice.yml")); ```

column3: Make it easier to inherit from dropwizard-parent
column4: The dropwizard-parent POM was using `${project.version}` for specifying the version of dropwizard-dependencies.  This prevented using it in projects in which the version is not a valid (and not the desired) Dropwizard version.  Refs #2897

column3: Archetype includes prerequisites tag, gives warning
column4: The dropwizard-archetype version 1.3.8 includes the 'prerequisites' tag: ```              3.0.0      ``` This is intended for maven-plugin projects only.  When you run `mvn package` for example, you will see this warning: ``` [WARNING] The project ... uses prerequisites which is only intended for maven-plugin projects but not for non maven-plugin projects. For such purposes you should use the maven-enforcer-plugin. See https://maven.apache.org/enforcer/enforcer-rules/requireMavenVersion.html ```

The dropwizard core 1.3.9 version (io.dropwizard:dropwizard-core:jar:1.3.9) is using jackson-databind:jar:2.9.8 which is having the vulnerability issue:: CVE-2019-12086. Is there any plan to mitigate this issue? Please suggest!

column3: Replace invalid default excludedProtocols in HttpsConnectorFactory
column4: The default list of excluded protocols used in `HttpsConnectorFactory` wasn't working as expected.  Jetty currently doesn't support using regular expressions for supported or excluded protocols. This is only working for supported and excluded _cipher suites_ as of Jetty 9.4.33.v20201020.  The default list of excluded protocols now only contains valid and complete entries:  SSLv3, TLSv1, and TLSv1.1  Refs https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/5531 Fixes #3532

column3: Dropwizard reporting incorrectly enabled HTTPS protocols
column4: The deafult Dropwizard behaviour seems to enable TLSv1.1 (despite the documentation stating that TLSv1.1 is in the excludedProtocols by default). It does also not match what is bieng logged by Dropwizard.  Steps to reproduce (using Dropwizard v.2.0.13): 1. Create a simple Dropwizard application. Add HTTPs configuration (do not set any values for supportedProtocols and excludedProtocols) 2. Start up server. Server logs indicate: `io.dropwizard.jersey.HttpsConnectorFactory: Enabled protocols: [TLSv1.2, TLSv1.3] io.dropwizard.jersey.HttpsConnectorFactory: Disabled protocols: [SSLv2Hello, SSLv3, TLSv1, TLSv1.1]` 3. `curl --tlsv1.1 https://localhost` - this actually works (using curl version: libcurl/7.29.0, NSS/3.44)  Further proof: - Add a `ServerLifecycleListener` with the `serverStarted` method as: `server -> LOGGER.info(Arrays.asList(server.getBean(SslContextFactory.class).getSelectedProtocols()))` - This will print TLSv1.1, TLSv1.2 and TLSv1.3  Notes: - If I explicitly set excludedProtocols with TLSv1.1, it gets disabled. - TLS 1.1 may still fail due to the default cipher suites prevent an algorithm agreement - but that is besides the point - the protocol is still enabled.

The current documentation (1.3.X) does not mention the built in support for JUnit 5 extensions added in #2166.   Documentation for 2.0.0 has an example of DropwizardClientExtension, but it there's no references or examples of ResourceExtensions, DropwizardAppExtension or DAOTestExtension.

The conscrypt documentation will appear to need a slight tweak to the recommended way of registering the provider.  https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3551 https://www.dropwizard.io/1.3.9/docs/manual/core.html#man-core-bootstrapping

column3: Upgrade Jetty to version 9.2.28, 9.3.27, 9.4.17 or higher.
column4: The configuration of a Jetty server may be leaked as part of a HTTP 404 response. This is due to the DefaultHandler class producing an error page during an exception.  More information on https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/3555

column3: Dropwizard BOM provides dependency management for modules outside the Dropwizard project
column4: The BOM is setting dependency management for modules that aren't part of Dropwizard. This is not ideal, as it can cause conflicts when other projects import the BOM.  A simple example would be if I had a project using the Dropwizard BOM, and also depending on something that depends on `tomcat-jdbc:9.0.8` and `tomcat-dbcp:9.0.8`. In this case I would get `tomcat-jdbc:9.0.22` from Dropwizard, and `tomcat-dbcp:9.0.8`, which might not work together. This will happen even if I don't use a Dropwizard module that requires `tomcat-jdbc`.  See a similar discussion here https://github.com/dropwizard/metrics/issues/1336  Ideally the BOM would only set the versions of io.dropwizard modules, and let the consuming project handle resolving any conflicts between transitive dependencies. This is also how several other modular projects do their BOMs (e.g. JUnit, Jackson, Camel)

column3: Remove alpn-boot dependency in dropwizard-http2 for Java 8u252
column4: The alpn-boot dependency is not required anymore starting with Java 8u251/8u252: https://github.com/jetty-project/jetty-alpn#jetty-alpn  > The ALPN APIs have been backported from Java 9 to OpenJDK 8u251/8u252. Therefore, since OpenJDK 8u251/8u252 there is no more need for the Jetty ALPN boot jar provided by this project.

column3: Default useForwardedHeaders setting leaves applications vulnerable to X-Forwarded-For spoofing
column4: The `useForwardedHeaders` setting in the [HTTP connector](https://www.dropwizard.io/1.3.9/docs/manual/configuration.html#man-configuration-http) is set to true by default. The documentation specifies that having this enabled will make Dropwizard honor `X-Forwarded-*` headers added by proxies (via the usage of Jetty's [ForwardedRequestCustomizer](https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/blob/jetty-9.4.x/jetty-server/src/main/java/org/eclipse/jetty/server/ForwardedRequestCustomizer.java)), but it's not clear what is meant by "look at", ie, what actually is affected by this setting.  One of the undocumented implications of having this turned on is that if the `X-Forwarded-For` HTTP header is set on the incoming request, it actually changes the output of `ServletRequest::getRemoteHost`. The [servlet spec](https://javaee.github.io/javaee-spec/javadocs/javax/servlet/ServletRequest.html#getRemoteAddr--) for this method specifies that the output of that method should be the IP address of the client or the last proxy that sent the request (ie, the IP address of the remote peer in the TCP connection), making no reference to `X-Forwarded-For` or any other HTTP headers, so this is an unexpected change.  An implication of this is that anyone that can manipulate the `X-Forwarded-For` HTTP header can cause Dropwizard to use a spoofed value both for its internal logging and by providing this spoofed value via `ServletRequest::getRemoteHost`, potentially bypassing access control restrictions or auditing that an application might implement if it relies on this value.  With that setting on, any Dropwizard API that is exposed to the Internet would be vunerable to this type of remote IP address spoofing, unless all public facing load balancers that could potentially serve as reverse proxies to said application are actively performing sanitization of the `X-Forwarded-For` header (clearing it out fully instead of just appending its own IP address to an already existing header). With either no load balancers configured in that way or when exposed directly to the Internet, any Dropwizard application that relies on `getRemoteHost` can be tricked into using arbitrary data set by a malicious party instead of the client's remote IP address – this includes the access logs generated by Dropwizard.  Ideally, the default for this option should be `false`, to avoid undesired insecure behavior for situations where Dropwizard is not deployed behind a reverse proxy that is actively performing this sanitization. However, since that could potentially break existing applications, at the very least, documentation should be ammended to that the default setting of `true` will cause `ServletRequest::getRemoteHost` and Dropwizard's access logs to return the leftmost value in the `X-Forwarded-For` HTTP header and that sanitization of that header by a public-facing reverse proxy would be necessary if full accuracy in identifying the remote address of the client is required.  This is fairly easy to reproduce; on a sample 1.3.9 Dropwizard project, with the default configuration, with a single resource, sending a request while setting the `X-Forwarded-For` header to `dummy`, the following is logged in the access logs: ```dummy - - [26/Feb/2019:11:02:35 +0000] "GET /test HTTP/1.1" 200 19 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36" 78```  After setting `useForwardedHeaders` to false and repeating the same request: ```127.0.0.1 - - [26/Feb/2019:11:25:56 +0000] "GET /test HTTP/1.1" 200 18 "-" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36" 86```

column3: Add data size class adhering to the correct SI and IEC prefixes
column4: The `Size` and `SizeUnit` classes in Dropwizard are using a common but incorrect definition of data size units, in which 1 kilobyte equals 1024 bytes.  The `DataSize` and `DataSizeUnit` classes are using the correct definitions according to SI and IEC, in which 1 kilobyte equals 1000 bytes and 1 kibibytes equals 1024 bytes.  Instead of modifying the existing `Size` and `SizeUnit` classes, this change set introduces a new set of classes, `DataSize` and `DataSizeUnit`, with the possibility to convert the old units into the new, correct units.  Example: ``` assertEquals(Size.parse("128 kb").toDataSize(), DataSize.kibibytes(128L)); ```  This is a breaking change and has to be properly documented in the release notes and upgrade notes of Dropwizard.  Closes #2152 Closes #2154

column3: Fix random port assignment in Resource
column4: The `JerseyTest` instance used by `Resource` didn't set `TestProperties.CONTAINER_PORT` properly so that the tests weren't run with a random port which caused problems when trying to run tests in parallel.
The `driverClass` configuration setting is only required if no JDBC drivers have been registered with the Java service loader (`META-INF/services/java.sql.Driver`).  Closes #3506
The `*Param` classes, except for `NonEmptyStringParam` will be removed in #2613.  This PR, deprecates them in the 1.3.x releases.

column3: Move to joschi/setup-jdk for GitHub Actions
column4: The [joschi/setup-jdk](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/setup-java-environment-based-on-adoptopenjdk) action supports the OpenJDK distributions from AdoptOpenJDK.  https://github.com/marketplace/actions/setup-java-environment-based-on-adoptopenjdk

column3: Wrong date labeled to the version 1.3.8
column4: The 1.3.8 version labeled by Jan 2, 2018 date while the actual year is 2019 (https://www.dropwizard.io/1.3.8/docs/about/index.html)

column3: Add support for logging caller data in dropwizard-json-logging
column4: The "callerData" event attribute in the "includes" configuration setting allows logging caller-specific details, such as:  * class name ("caller_class_name") * method name ("caller_method_name") * file name ("caller_file_name") * line number ("caller_line_number")  Closes #2539

column3: Support for requestAttributes in Json access log
column4: Summary ======= Support for requestAttributes similar to LogbackAccessLayout. When specified, all non-null values will be included in logs  ###### Problem: We were using servletFilters to populate certain application specific contextual information and pass them along as request attributes, which are in turn used for central logging of access logs. Lack of way to specify request Attributes in json log layout is hindering us to move to json logging instead of file logging.   ###### Solution: * Added configuration support to specify requestAttribute names to be logged.  * Retrieving the attribute from `IAccessEvent#getAttribute()` api to add them to json log

column3: 2.0.0:  Registering org.glassfish.hk2.utilities.binding.AbstractBinder fails with java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Provider registered to Hk2InjectionManager cannot be process because of incompatible type: class java.lang.Class
column4: Starting with  jersey 2.29 `org.glassfish.hk2.utilities.binding.AbstractBinder` can again be registered with jersey's `ResourceConfig` , see eclipse-ee4j/jersey#4092. However `DropwizardResourceConfig.register`  attempts to create a dynamic proxy for instances of hk2  `AbstractBinder` which result in a failure.   The `DropwizardResourceConfig.register` should simpy delecate to jersey `ResourceConfig.register` for instances of `org.glassfish.hk2.utilities.binding.AbstractBinder`

column3: Allow overriding default media type in AssetServlet/AssetBundle
column4: Sometimes the default media type of `text/html` in the `AssetServlet` and `AssetBundle` might not be the best fit for every use case.  This PR exposes a setting to specify the default media type for `AssetBundle` and `AssetServlet` and override the default of `text/html`.

column3: How to log logs with different log levels to different files in Dropwizard?
column4: So Basically what I want to do is to log logs with different logs levels like INFO DEBUG WARN etc to different log files.  I have found something similar for slf4j [here](https://dzone.com/articles/log4j-tutorial-%E2%80%93-writing) but dropwizard uses logback as logging framework.  Can anybody tell me how to do it in dropwizard with logback? What changes should I make in my conifg.yml file?  ```  level: INFO   loggers:     "io.dropwizard": INFO     "org.hibernate.SQL":       level: DEBUG       additive: false       appenders:         - type: file           currentLogFilename: /var/log/myapplication-sql.log           archivedLogFilenamePattern: /var/log/myapplication-sql-%d.log.gz           archivedFileCount: 5 ```

column3: Upgrade to SnakeYAML to address CVE-2017-18640
column4: SnakeYAML < 1.26 is vulnerable to a Billion Laughs attack (denial of service).  * https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-18640 * https://bitbucket.org/asomov/snakeyaml/issues/377  Refs FasterXML/jackson-dataformats-text#187 Refs #3223

column3: Upgrade to SnakeYAML to address CVE-2017-18640
column4: SnakeYAML < 1.26 is vulnerable to a Billion Laughs attack (denial of service).  * https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-18640 * https://bitbucket.org/asomov/snakeyaml/issues/377  Refs FasterXML/jackson-dataformats-text#187 Refs #3223

Since dropwizard 2.0 `HttpServletRequest` injected by `@Context` no longer contains scheme  See image: ![Skjermbilde 2020-01-29 kl  16 24 23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/414079/73370209-25909400-42b4-11ea-8c92-fa0897e8830c.png)  This causes a problem, even though we terminate SSL before the app, we still want to get the URI a client requested.   One example is Hawk tokens. They are created on the client using the URI you want to request and some shared secret. Then it is recreated on the server using the requested URI and the same secret and compared. However since the scheme is no longer in the request it default to `http://` and if the client requested a `https://` url we wont be able to match the token.
Since checkstyle was removed in #2693 , disabling it in the codeclimate config in order to fix the badge
Signed-off-by: Abhilash Gnan   Minor fix in testing docs
see https://search.maven.org/artifact/io.dropwizard/dropwizard-core/1.3.16/bom

column3: Upgrade Apache httpclient to 4.5.10 to fix URI rewriting
column4: See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTTPCLIENT-1968 for detailed background.  ###### Problem: 4.5.7 introduced a change to normalize URIs by removing repeated forward slashes.  However, this broke encoded reserved characters in the URI, such as the forward slash itself (`%2F`).  I've been running into this while using the latest Dropwizard 1.3 release.  Example URI that fails: `http://localhost/math/1%2F2` (gets converted to `http://localhost/math/1/2` prior to the request being made)  ###### Solution: 4.5.8 fixed this issue, but .9 and .10 included good fixes as well, so bump up to 4.5.10.  ###### Result: See the release notes for the list of fixes: https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-client/blob/4.5.10/RELEASE_NOTES.txt
see https://github.com/jetty-project/jetty-alpn/commit/0d70cb95c21cf7bca35308e2ab261b6cc1c0884f

see #2496  ###### Problem: in DropwizardTestSupport the test support class sets the bootstrap ConfigurationFactoryFactory before initializing the application  ###### Solution: moved application initialization before overwriting the configurationfactoryfactory in the TestSupport  ###### Result: ConfigurationFactoryFactory can be changed in app and the app can still be tested

column3: Run downstream Maven builds in quiet mode
column4: Reduce output of downstream Maven builds to reduce the overall log size of the Travis CI builds.  Otherwise, we might run into problems with the overall log output: > The job exceeded the maximum log length, and has been terminated.
reduce noise in the CI build by adding Maven's --no-transfer-progress parameter

Pull dependency updates into `release/1.3.x` branch as far as it makes sense.  There are no functional changes in Dropwizard itself except for a few tests which behave differently with different Java versions.  I've tried to have one commit per change so that we can revert/remove changes we do not want to have in the Dropwizard 1.3.x line.  Everything _should_ be backwards-compatible but I'm planning to publish at least one release candidate for Dropwizard 1.3.25 so that people can easier test it.

Processing a configuration class with self-referencing fields could lead to an `OutOfMemoryError`.  To prevent this, multiple safe guards have been added:  - Reduce recursion depth from 100 to 10 levels - Check for loops in the parents of a property - Take `@JsonIgnore` annotation into account  Fixes #3528

Problem The conditional expression is not easy to read.  Solution: Simplify conditional expression  Result: made it easier to read  This commitment supports to open source community for **Hacktoberfest**.

Prior to DropWizard 2.0.0, it was possible to use a configuration interface in a ConfiguredBundle to indicate that you expected a certain subset of configuration to be passed in which implemented that interface; in the 2.0.0-rc1 version of dropwizard, the ConfiguredBundle type parameter is now set to `T extends Configuration` making that no longer possible.  ``` public class MyBundle implements ConfiguredBundle {      @Override     public void initialize(final Bootstrap bootstrap) {     }      @Override     public void run(final HasMyConfig myConfig, final Environment environment) {     } } ``` ``` public interface HasMyConfig {      @NotNull     @Valid     @JsonProperty("mine")     MyConfig getMyConfig(); } ```  The documentation still notes it as supported: https://dropwizard.readthedocs.io/en/rtd/manual/core.html#bundles  And the migration guide does not make any mention of this breaking change: https://dropwizard.readthedocs.io/en/rtd/manual/upgrade-notes/upgrade-notes-2_0_x.html  Could you please either a) update the documentation to reflect the change (and hopefully a workaround to enable this some other way) or b) revert the change to ConfiguredBundle's type parameter to resolve this?

column3: Fix thread safety issue with eTag calculation.
column4: Previously, a static CRC32 instance was created and shared across requests. When assets are requested across multiple threads, the underlying CRC32 could be calculated inconsistently.  Updated the code to create a new CRC32 instance for each request. Alternatively, a ThreadLocal could be used if this is determined to be a major performance issue.  Fixes #3119.

Optimization/Features/Suggestions around managed executors 1. The current default thread factory creates a new DefaultThreadFactory instance whenever a new thread is constructed.   2. For threads we have a global counter. Would prefer a counter per executor service (Use a global pool and local thread number similar to DefaultThreadFactory). Can move threadFactory logic to its own class. Would've extended threadFactory but its a private static class. 3. nameFormat seems very unintuitive. It's not clear to users that they have to specify one. Also its usage across classes vary. (ScheduledExecutorServiceBuilder doesn't have that requirement). 4. People who aren't familiar with the ThreadPoolExecutor may run into issues like https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/2553 when using the ExecutorServiceBuilder.    PR for point 1 - https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/3285  For points 2, 3 and 4, I've created a draft PR and mentioned changes below. Don't think anything here can be considered as breaking changes. Can update release notes/docs/tests if you think this is a reasonable approach - https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/3286  - User passes a prefix and the threadFactory will add pool/thread number.  - Whatever the user passes is what is used in the metric name. The methods getNameWithoutFormat in this https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/3142 will return a string appended to itself, so it may have to be reverted. @pkwarren - Any feedback/concerns? - Includes managed and instrumented executor service factory methods. ThreadPoolExecutor Javadocs urges users to use the Executors factory methods that preconfigure settings for the most common usage scenarios. Also the InstrumentedExecutorService has additional metrics like idle/duration timers which InstrumentedThreadFactory (used in ExecutorServiceBuilder) doesn't have
Old project: https://github.com/findbugsproject/findbugs New project: https://github.com/spotbugs/spotbugs

column3: Overlapping classes in dropwizard-example shaded jar in 2.0.0-rc9
column4: Observed these when building dropwizard-example as well as our own app, so looks like a regression. ``` [WARNING] jakarta.xml.bind-api-2.3.2.jar, jaxb-api-2.3.1.jar define 111 overlapping classes:  [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlValue [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlElement [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.annotation.adapters.XmlJavaTypeAdapter [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.ContextFinder [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.ContextFinder$3 [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlElementRefs [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.helpers.DefaultValidationEventHandler [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.ParseConversionEvent [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlSchema [WARNING]   - javax.xml.bind.ValidationException [WARNING]   - 101 more... column3: Upgrade to official Jackson fix for preventing a DoS attack
column4: Now Jackson automatically coerces very small and very big integers, so we can remove our custom deserializers introduced in #2511.

Noticed that latest jetty release (9.4.33) was not binary compatible with latest dropwizard release (2.0.14) and filed an issue with jetty to let them know they've broken binary (but not source) compatibility.  They are not going to revert back, but did question if NonBlockingServletHolder is still necessary, more details here:  https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/5496#issuecomment-716398885
Newer versions of Java need to run error-prone as a compiler plugin. Update the profile for Java 9+ builds to run with error-prone plug-in and same arguments that are used for Java 1.8 build.

column3: Start moving example code from docs to runnable code
