column3: Change between http/https using env vars?
column4: Most probably like everyone else, my DW configuration uses env vars substitution. This works 90% of the time but fails to work when changing a config value requires adding or removing other config properties, like in our app connectors:  I've tried the following, in hopes of supporting both `http` and `https`: ```   applicationConnectors:     - type: ${APP_HTTP_CONNECTOR:-http}       port: ${APP_HTTP_PORT:-8080}       keyStorePath: ${APP_HTTP_KEY_STORE_PATH:-null}       keyStorePassword: ${APP_HTTP_KEY_STORE_PASSWORD:-null}       keyStoreType: ${APP_HTTP_KEY_STORE_TYPE:-null} ```  Which works for `https` when I provide the env vars above. The problem is, as soon as the `type` field is `http`, I get a config validation error: ```   * Unrecognized field at: server.applicationConnectors.[0].keyStorePath     Did you mean?:       - port       - bindHost       - idleTimeout       - useDateHeader       - selectorThreads         [20 more] ```  Because it's trying to set `keyStorePath` field on the `HttpConnectorFactory`.  1. Is this doable in some other way that I missed? 2. If not, do you agree that it's reasonable to support that functionality? If yes, we could start discussing possible simple approaches to supporting that kind of thing.
Minor cleanups taken and updated from #2538.

column3: Liquibase: CreateViewGenerator generates incorrect SQL for PostgreSQL
column4: Migration from 1.3 to 2.0 exposes issue with view replacement. Not a dropwizard issue, but creating a placeholder to track and incorporate when fixed https://github.com/liquibase/liquibase/issues/1042
Many Maven plugins and other tools needed to automate releases don't support the Dropwizard version being used from a global property in POM files.
Many Maven plugins and other tools needed to automate releases don't support the Dropwizard version being used from a global property in POM files.

column3: Jackson Afterburner don't use value classloader
column4: Make Afterburner generate bytecode only for public getters/setter and fields to avoid Java 9+ complains of "Illegal reflective access".  Resolves #2909

column3: HOWTO change response body of 403 Forbidden?
column4: Let a resource method be annotated with `@RolesAllowed(value = { "USER" })`. The principal does not have this role so a `403 Forbidden` response is returned.  The body of this response has `Content-Type: application/json`:  ```json {   "code": 403,   "message": "User not authorized." } ```  How can I change the content type of this response and return a custom body?  A possible use case could be to return a `text/html` response body which contains HTML that explains that the user is not authorized.
Just wanted to give a heads up that Jersey 2.29 was just released http://blog.supol.cz/?p=144 Would be great if the new DW version 2 could support the new Jersey version!  Thank you!

column3: Jetty , dropwizard issue, metrics already exist
column4: jetty version: 9.4.28.v20200408 dropwizardv version=4.1.7 JDK 11  metrics-core-4.1.7.jar metrics-healthchecks-4.1.7.jar metrics-jetty9-4.1.7.jar metrics-json-4.1.7.jar metrics-jvm-4.1.7.jar metrics-servlets-4.1.7.jar  Just upgraded  version of dropwizard and jetty, now I get the following error when starting my application:  ``` Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: A metric named org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletContextHandler.percent-4xx-1m already exists 	at com.codahale.metrics.MetricRegistry.register(MetricRegistry.java:156) 	at com.codahale.metrics.jetty9.InstrumentedHandler.doStart(InstrumentedHandler.java:143) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle.start(AbstractLifeCycle.java:72) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.ContainerLifeCycle.start(ContainerLifeCycle.java:169) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.ContainerLifeCycle.doStart(ContainerLifeCycle.java:117) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.server.handler.AbstractHandler.doStart(AbstractHandler.java:97) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle.start(AbstractLifeCycle.java:72) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.ContainerLifeCycle.start(ContainerLifeCycle.java:169) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.server.Server.start(Server.java:407) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.ContainerLifeCycle.doStart(ContainerLifeCycle.java:110) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.server.handler.AbstractHandler.doStart(AbstractHandler.java:97) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.server.Server.doStart(Server.java:371) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle.start(AbstractLifeCycle.java:72) ```

JDBI 2.x was last updated in [January 2017](https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.jdbi/jdbi), so it's safe to say that [Jdbi 3](https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.jdbi/jdbi3-core) is now only support major version of the library.  Therefore we can move `dropwizard-jdbi` out of the Dropwizard core modules and into its own repository at https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard-jdbi.  The migration path for existing users is fairly simple: Replacing the old Maven artifact coordinates with the new artifact coordinates:  ```xml       io.dropwizard     dropwizard-jdbi     ${project.version}  ``` ```xml       io.dropwizard.modules     dropwizard-jdbi     ${project.version}  ```

column3: Log all request and response headers
column4: It would be nice to have a flag to allow all request headers and all response headers to be logged instead of having to specify which ones we want.

column3: Unpinned JDK version in CircleCI settings.
column4: It seems that Debian based distributions have moved to 8u191 and replaced the one off 8u181b13 (current release for Ubuntu 18 is 8u191b12).  ###### Problem: Due to a strange one-off build of Java (8u181b13), a number of things broke within Maven builds (surefire, Jetty, etc...). With the release of an official OpenJDK build to Debian, CircleCI should in theory work without pinning the version to the older, 8u171.  I have tested building DropWizard under 8u191 and it builds without issue.  ###### Solution: Removed the pinned version.  ###### Result: The build should succeed.

column3: DropwizardTestSupport change in Dropwizard 2.x RC overwrites ConfigurationSourceProvider set by application
column4: It seems that a change (https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/commit/86abeb0a187fd5c80488ba21324aaa16dabde6a3) in the Dropwizard 2.x RC in the `DropwizardTestSupport.startIfRequired(...)` method breaks some of our current usages. We currently use Dropwizard 1.3.9, for context.  Specifically, if any bundles set the `ConfigurationSourceProvider`, this line in `DropwizardTestSupport` overwrites whatever the app set one line earlier: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/commit/86abeb0a187fd5c80488ba21324aaa16dabde6a3#diff-0c89d4d1401a3b757bcfd634613fc073R291, which breaks the expected behavior of our tests.   We have a `ConfigurationSourceProvider` that is added via a bundle, which replaces tokens in the config.yml file with overrides specified elsewhere. The result is that this `ConfigurationSourceProvider` is overwritten in our tests.
It appears that a release/2.0.x branch has been created and I see a milestone for 2.1.0. Should the master branch be updated to 2.1.0-SNAPSHOT?

column3: Add GitHub workflow to close stale issues and PRs
column4: Issues and PRs will be marked as stale after 90 days and removed if there wasn't any activity 14 days after that.  Refs #2884 Refs #2888 Refs actions/stale#8

column3: Add GitHub workflow to close stale issues and PRs
column4: Issues and PRs will be marked as stale after 90 days and removed if there wasn't any activity 14 days after that.

Is there a way to take advantage of all the good features of drop wizard such as yaml configuration, logging, healtchecks, metrics and so on for a not restful service?  For instance for a real-time processing service using Kafka?  Kind regards

column3: Dropwizard-hibernate set isolation level per transaction
column4: Is there a way to set custom isolation level per transaction using dropwizard-hibernate as it is possible to do with Spring Data JPA and Spring DI?  If no, is there any limitation preventing this feature to be added?  I also ask about this here on [stack overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/q/58864732/1431656) where I provided a fully working code [repository](https://github.com/jeep87c/dropwizard-guice-springDataJPA-hibernate)  with the same stack I'm using for my real life scenario.  Thank you

Instead of requiring the `driverClass` property in the configuration, driver classes listed in `META-INF/services/java.sql.Driver` should be [checked for support](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/15/docs/api/java.sql/java/sql/Driver.html#acceptsURL(java.lang.String)) of the given JDBC URL.  https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/e3b71b15ab17ae56c37eaccfb56437c95d8eff20/dropwizard-db/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/db/DataSourceFactory.java#L35-L37  https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/e3b71b15ab17ae56c37eaccfb56437c95d8eff20/dropwizard-db/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/db/DataSourceFactory.java#L332-L333

column3: Move upgrade notes from GitHub wiki into documentation
column4: Instead of maintaining multiple places where users have to check for information, let's move the upgrade notes for Dropwizard into the documentation.

Instead of just exiting the application by default (`Application#onFatalError()`) in case a command failed, the `Application#onFatalError(Throwable)` method allows reacting to different causes of the failure.  Closes #3014 Closes #3015

Instead of hosting the Dropwizard documentation on GitHub pages and having to update the `gh-pages` branch (semi-) manually after each release, we can use https://readthedocs.org/ which will take care of building the documentation and serving it in multiple versions.  While the original Dropwizard theme could be used on ReadTheDocs, the official RTD theme providers some features which we would have to add to the original theme, such as:  * Search function * Version selection * Automatic sitemap generation

column3: Hibernate validation on max threads doesn't match required threads
column4: In the `AbstractServerFactory`, the `maxThreads` field is annotated with `@Min(2L)`. Dropwizard fails to start with an `IllegalStateException`:  ``` java.lang.IllegalStateException: Insufficient configured threads: required=2 < max=2 for InstrumentedQueuedThreadPool[dw]@296b758{STARTED,1

column3: Generate and publish aggregated Dropwizard Javadoc artifact
column4: In order to use third party services such as https://javadoc.io/ effectively, there should be an aggregated Javadoc artifact which includes the documentation for all official Dropwizard modules.

In order to properly support the Java Platform Module System (JPMS), the packages in modules must not overlap, or put differently, the packages may not be split into multiple modules.  See also: https://nipafx.dev/java-9-migration-guide/#split-packages  This change set cleans up the overlapping package structure where necessary (and is unfortunately breaking backward compatibility).  Affected packages:  - `dropwizard-core`: `io.dropwizard` -> `io.drowizard.core` - `dropwizard-views`: `io.dropwizard.views` -> `io.dropwizard.views.common` - `dropwizard-metrics`: `io.dropwizard.metrics` -> `io.dropwizard.metrics.common` - `dropwizard-logging`: `io.dropwizard.logging` -> `io.dropwizard.logging.common`  Refs https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/2926 Refs https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/3131 Refs https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/3654

In my tests, it seems that the `@UnitOfWork` on a resource is closed too early, before `StreamingOutput` has finished executing. So the following fails:  ``` // Some service: class SomeService {   Stream stream() {     // Return JPA/Hibernate entities   } }  // The Resource @UnitOfWork Response someResource() {   Stream stream = someService.stream(...)     // Just a dummy operation, in reality this map is an expensive operation     .map(Entity::toString);    return Response.ok(new StreamingOutput() {     void write(out) {       // ... code to wrap out in bufferedwriter, etc ... //        stream.forEach(line -> {         out.write(line);       });      out.flush();     }   }).build(); } ```  The purpose of JAX-RS `StreamingOutput` is a pattern like the above, where instead of buffering the contents in the server memory we are delaying the expensive operation (the `Stream.map` here) and instead do it one by one as we write to the output stream. The above code doesn't work in Dropwizard because by the time `StreamingOutput` is executing the `@UnitOfWork` is closed.  I believe the fix should be simple, in `UnitOfWorkApplicationListener` we would move the call `unitOfWorkAspect.afterEnd()` from `RequestEvent.Type.RESP_FILTERS_START` to `RequestEvent.Type.FINISHED` instead.  Please let me know if any more details are required. If there are no objections with this change I'd happily work on a PR.

In Dropwizard 1.3.x and earlier, Jersey interpreted empty strings in parameters (`@CookieParam`, `@QueryParam`, etc.) identical to `null` as missing and used the default value (`@DefaultValue`) as fall-back if it existed.  This change set restores the described behavior in Dropwizard 2.x for the classes inheriting from `AbstractParam`.  Keep in mind that `AbstractParam` and its child classes are deprecated and will be removed in a later Dropwizard version in favor of using `Optional` directly.  Refs #3123 Refs #3134

column3: Add current class loader to javassist ClassPool
column4: In certain environments (eg AWS Lambda), the default/system class loader doesn't have dropwizard classes in it.  Use the current class's class loader to ensure that it does.  ###### Problem: In certain environments (eg AWS Lambda), the default/system class loader doesn't have dropwizard classes in it, and we see the following: ``` javassist.NotFoundException: io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig$SpecificBinder     at javassist.ClassPool.get(ClassPool.java:422)     at io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig.register(DropwizardResourceConfig.java:152) ``` ###### Solution: Use the current class's class loader to ensure that it does.  ###### Result: Running dropwizard in aws lambda works (with some glue between an aws RequestHandler and the dropwizard application's resourceConfig).  Running as a standard shaded jar also still works. Note that I don't know a good way to write a test for this, as the failure is dependent on aws lambda's underlying jvm implementation.

If there is some custom serialization/deserialization happening in a dependency included with dropwizard, dropwizard jersey is unable to identify it until unless the custom serializers/deserializers are registered manually via code with jersey.  ``` @JsonSerialize(using = MapValueSerializer.class) @JsonDeserialize(using = MapValueDeserializer.class) public class MapValue extends Value { //some code } ```  Below has to be done explicitly to ensure that the ser/deser are available to jersey, which is not a nice way! ```         environment.jersey().register(MapValueDeserializer.class);         environment.jersey().register(MapValueSerializer.class); ```  If this is not done, jackson is not able to do ser/deser of `MapValue` and throws exception.

If I run the following code to retry to connect to my database the exception never gets caught since the run method catches the exception already by itself.  ```java public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {     while (true) {       try {         new Application().run(args);         return;       } catch (SQLException ex) {         System.out.println("Retry connecting to database...");         continue;       }     }   } ```  Is there any workaround for this without editing the code of the run method so I can catch the exception by myself?  Thanks, Leon

column3: Swallow EofException when response was incomplete
column4: If a client drops the connection before a response was completely sent, Jetty will emit an `org.eclipse.jetty.io.EofException` which is then caught by Jersey and logged.  This can quite noisy in the logs and should typically be swallowed instead of logged including the stack trace.  The introduced `EofExceptionWriterInterceptor` will catch `EofException` which are being thrown while writing and will swallow them (after logging on DEBUG level).  Refs #2482 Refs #2541 Refs eclipse/jetty.project#544

If a `@Path` is missing the preceding slash it is no longer being implicitly added by jersey.  ```java package io.mattnelson.resources;  import javax.ws.rs.GET; import javax.ws.rs.Path;  @Path("path") public class PathResource {     @GET     @Path("child1")     public Object one() {return null; }     @GET     @Path("child2")     public Object two() { return null; } } ```  Paths with 1.3.14 > INFO  [2019-09-10 21:43:14,490] io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig: The following paths were found for the configured resources:     GET     /path/child1 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)     GET     /path/child2 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)  Paths with 2.0.0-rc9 > INFO  [2019-09-10 21:47:01,015] io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig: The following paths were found for the configured resources:     GET     /pathchild1 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)     GET     /pathchild2 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)  Updating to include slashes results in the same available paths as with 1.3.14. ```java @Path("path") public class PathResource {     @GET     @Path("/child1")     public Object one() {return null; }     @GET     @Path("/child2")     public Object two() { return null; } } ```  > INFO  [2019-09-10 21:51:07,313] io.dropwizard.jersey.DropwizardResourceConfig: The following paths were found for the configured resources:     GET     /path/child1 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)     GET     /path/child2 (io.mattnelson.resources.PathResource)   Possibly related to https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/jersey/issues/4040 or https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/jersey/issues/4119

I've tried upgrading our project to 2.0.0-rc1, however upon integration testing I'm seeing the following error:  ``` java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class io.dropwizard.validation.valuehandling.GuavaOptionalValueExtractor 	at io.dropwizard.validation.BaseValidator.newConfiguration(BaseValidator.java:26) 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.validation.Validators.newConfiguration(Validators.java:33) 	at io.dropwizard.jersey.validation.Validators.newValidatorFactory(Validators.java:26) 	at io.dropwizard.setup.Bootstrap.(Bootstrap.java:64) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.DropwizardTestSupport$2.(DropwizardTestSupport.java:273) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.DropwizardTestSupport.startIfRequired(DropwizardTestSupport.java:273) ```  There is nothing obvious in my own configuration that should be causing this, and the validation dependency is present in the project and thus should be on the classpath.

I've stumbled across a problem that is extremely difficult to reproduce in simple code.    Quite simply, if a dropwizard server is bootstrapped for a unit test via DropwizardSupport, no matter what modules are registered in client or server code, java.time.Instant is not serialized properly.  Instead of printing either epoch time, or ISO date format, jackson/jersey are serializing   like this: ````       "featureTime": {             "epochSecond": 1602516947,             "nano": 202000000         } ````  This does not get read properly then by a client using the same bean definition.  THe same code works perfectly when running as a standalone server.  Something about running in DropwizardSupport is messing up customised serialization.  Dropwizard 2.0.13 Jackson 2.10.5 Java 8

I've seen 1.3.10 has been released but there's no details on the release page https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/releases to show what's changed as per past releases.  From looking at the commits (https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/commits/release/1.3.x) I think this is just a bump of Jetty from 9.4.14.v20181114 to 9.4.17.v20190418.  Am I right and are there any other notable changes?

column3: Dropwizard 0.7 to 1.32: ResourceTest to ResourceTestRule breaks tests
column4: I've going through a legacy dropwizard codebase (v0.7) that i'm trying to bump up slightly to v1.3.2 and struggling with getting the resource test migrated and passed. Given the following Configuration:  ``` public class DemoConfiguration extends Configuration {     @Valid     @Getter     @NotNull     @JsonProperty("foo")     private String foo;      @Valid     @Getter     @NotNull     @JsonProperty("bar")     private String bar;      // Many others     ... } ```  and the following Resource:  ``` package com.demo;  import java.util.HashMap; import javax.ws.rs.Consumes; import javax.ws.rs.GET; import javax.ws.rs.Path; import javax.ws.rs.Produces; import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;  @Path("/") @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON) @Consumes(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON) public class DemoResource {      private String foo;     private String bar;    public DemoResource(DemoConfiguration config) {          this.foo = config.getFoo();         this.bar = config.getBar();          checkNullOrEmpty(foo);         checkNullOrEmpty(bar);          // Many other questionable decisions         ...   }    @GET   @Path("/demo")   public HashMap getHealth() {     HashMap map = new HashMap();     map.put("foo", foo);     map.put("bar", bar);     return map;   } } ```  And the change i've made to the resource test from the following:  ``` // 0.7 dropwizard resource testing public class DemoResourceTest extends ResourceTest {      private static final DemoConfiguration demoConfiguration = mock(DemoConfiguration.class);  	@Override 	protected void setUpResources() throws Exception {        when(demoConfiguration.getFoo()).thenReturn("me");       when(demoConfiguration.getBar()).thenReturn("me too");  		// now create the resource for this test 	    addResource(new CollectionResource(demoConfiguration)); 	}  	@Test 	public void demoTest() throws IOException { 		Response rsp = resources.target("/demo").request().get();         assertThat(rsp.getStatus()).isEqualTo(200);     } } ```  To the following (1.3.2):  ```  // 1.3.2 dropwizard resource testing public class DemoResourceTest {      private static final DemoConfiguration demoConfiguration = mock(DemoConfiguration.class);      @ClassRule     public static final ResourceTestRule resources = ResourceTestRule.builder()             .addResource(new DemoResource(demoConfiguration))             .build();        @Before     public void setup() {        when(demoConfiguration.getFoo()).thenReturn("me");       when(demoConfiguration.getBar()).thenReturn("me too");     }      @Test     public void demoTest() {       Response rsp = resources.target("/demo").request().get();       assertThat(rsp.getStatus()).isEqualTo(200);     } } ```  The test fail, because `@ClassRule` is called first which initializes the `DemoResource` before I've had the chance to set the values for the mock (which happen in the `@Before` step).  Is there a way to make this work, where i can setup and pass the mocked instance of `DemoConfiguration` to the constructor of `DemoResource`? The alternative would be to create an instance of every single one of those Configuration (and other deps) passed into the constructor manually which would be impossible given the no. of properties.  I've tried moving the `ResourceTestRule` into `@Before` step but that doesn't work either. Does anyone know the proper way to fix this?

column3: Hibernate seems to be bootstrapped twice
column4: I've been debugging the slow Dropwizard bootstrap times and I've noticed something suspicious. The bootstrap of the Hibernate from `dropwizard-hibernate` seems to happen twice causing noticeable amount of slowdown (30-50ms in the real project), because the `BootstrapServiceRegistry` is instantiated and configured twice.  This can be observed by putting breakpoint inside the constructor of `IntegratorServiceImpl` class from Hibernate and then bootstrapping `dropwizard` with `HibernateBundle`. The first instance comes from [instantiating `Configuration`](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-hibernate/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/hibernate/SessionFactoryFactory.java#L72) and second one from [instantiating `StandardServiceRegistryBuilder`](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-hibernate/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/hibernate/SessionFactoryFactory.java#L89) just below. According to the JavaDoc from the Hibernate's `Configuration` class internally it uses newer bootstrap approach (which as I understand is `StandardServiceRegistryBuilder`). So it kinda doesn't make sense to use both at the same time.  It seems that the fix may require some breaking changes to the public API to fix this problem. I'll try to take a stub at it later today.

column3: Can't generate UUID id using dropwizard-hibernate.
column4: I'm using Postgres  and dropwizard-hibernate 1.3.7.  The configuration below works just fine in a Spring application using Spring Data JPA without the need for a hibernate_sequence table.. but with dropwizard when trying to persist an entity it keeps asking for the sequence table.  I tried many different combinations of annotations but it seems that it always takes the default config which it seems to be SEQUENCE and looks for the hibernate_sequence table instead of using the generic generator specified in the annotations.   ```   @Id   @GeneratedValue(generator="system-uuid")   @GenericGenerator(name="system-uuid", strategy = "uuid2")   @Column(name = "id", unique = true)    private UUID id; ```  Problem was fixed.. it was actually an issue with Hibernate Envers that needed the sequence.  This can be closed/deleted.

column3: issues with ProxyPass and certificates in 2.0.12
column4: I'm upgrading from 1.3.12 to 2.0.12 and got everything working fine. But once I put it in production where SSL is needed, it fails to work. Normally it works and looks like this:  ``SSLProxyEngine On ProxyPass / https://my.example.com:12333/``  The whole project runs on https://my.example.com/ . Now after the update as soon as a POST comes along the way, it redirects to https://my.example.com:12333/ and declares an unsafe page. When looking for the used certificate, it claims "localhost". As soon as I roll back to 1.3.12, everything works just fine again.  ``server:   applicationConnectors:     - type: https       port: 12333       validateCerts: false``  That's the config side in the yml. What changed?

column3: default value not applied to optional parameter type
column4: I'm updating my application from 1.3.16 to dropwizard 2 and have changed the parameter on a method from a `LongParam` to `OptionalLong` as detailed in the deprecation warning for `LongParam`.   I've also changed my code to call `getAsLong()` now that the parameter type no longer has a `get()` method.  Here's the code following updating to dropwizard 2.   ``` 	@ExceptionMetered 	@GET 	@Path("/search") 	@Timed 	@ApiOperation( 			value="search", 			tags="Search", 			notes="Searches all records") 	@ApiResponses(value = 			{ @ApiResponse(code = 400, message = "'fromId' parameter is mandatory") }) 	public ResultPage search( 			@Auth final ServiceUser user, 			@QueryParam("fromId") @DefaultValue("0") final OptionalLong fromId, 			@QueryParam("department") final Set departments, 			@QueryParam("area") final Set areas) {  		final Long idFrom = fromId.getAsLong(); 		final List records = tenancyDao.execute(idFrom, departments, areas);  		return new ResultPageFactory(pageLimit).build(records); 	} ```  However now my `DefaultValue` annotation on the parameter no longer seems to be getting set when no value is passed to the parameter. This causes the exception from `fromId.getAsLong()` but I would expect it to always have a value due to the default value: ``` ! java.util.NoSuchElementException: No value present ! at java.util.OptionalLong.getAsLong(OptionalLong.java:118) ```  Debugging through has led me to [this line in `SingleValueExtractor`](https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/jersey/blob/2.29.1/core-server/src/main/java/org/glassfish/jersey/server/internal/inject/SingleValueExtractor.java#L61): ``` return fromString((value == null && isDefaultValueRegistered()) ? getDefaultValueString() : value); ```  At this point `value` is `""` (empty string) so although `isDefaultValueRegistered()` is `true`, it uses `value` instead of the default value.   **What do I need to do to get it to use the default value when none is set, as it did with dropwizard 1.3.x?**  Note before I updated my code to use `OptionalLong` I was getting `java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: ""` from [this line in `AbstractParam`](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/release/2.0.x/dropwizard-jersey/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/jersey/params/AbstractParam.java#L35) when the `LongParam` constructor was called, but the cause was the same: my param had a value of empty string instead of the default.

column3: 2.X.X deprecates UUIDParam, SizeParam, LocalDateParam, InstantParam, DurationParam, DateTimeParam, BooleanParam and does not give clear alternatives
column4: I'm trying to upgrade Dropwizard from 1.3.23 to 2.0.10 and am running into some issues around the use of parameters. Specifically, I see that [this commit](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/commit/69f6e77a19778aeb9a0c5bab897c5e8363ca1dbb) deprecated a number of *Param classes.  Some of these, like `IntParam` are straightfoward. Using `OptionalInt` as a replacement makes sense. However, taking non-primitive parameters as an example, `Optional` is NOT a sufficient replacement for `UUIDParam`. Using it results in me getting a 404 when using a non-UUID as input (where I previously got 400 using UUIDParam).  Additionally, and maybe this is a separate issue, I found the compatibility-preserving use of UUIDParam is strange. When diving into the source code, I found this resource method[[1]]:  ```         @GET         @Path("/uuid")         public String getUUID(@QueryParam("uuid") Optional uuid) {             return uuid.orElse(new UUIDParam("d5672fa8-326b-40f6-bf71-d9dacf44bcdc")).get().toString();         } ```  This construct seems an extremely clunky way to manage this. In 1.3.X, I could write code like this instead:  ```         @GET         @Path("/uuid")         public String getUUID(@Nullable @QueryParam("uuid") UUIDParam uuid) {             if (uuid != null) {                 return uuid.get()             } else {                 return "d5672fa8-326b-40f6-bf71-d9dacf44bcdc"             }         } ```  You can see in the above that there is a lot of unnecessary conversion going on (we construct a UUID via UUIDParam and validate it, even though we just want to return a String). I use Kotlin primarily, my preferred example above would be even simpler:  ``` uuid.get()?.toString ?: "d5672fa8-326b-40f6-bf71-d9dacf44bcdc" ``` What I'd prefer overall is something that worked like this:  ```         @GET         @Path("/uuid")         public String getUUID(@Nullable @QueryParam("uuid") Optional uuid) {             return uuid.map { it.toString() }.orElse("d5672fa8-326b-40f6-bf71-d9dacf44bcdc")         } ```  More than anything, really, I just want some guidance for the right way to handle various param types, especially in light of the deprecation. The documentation is light on this (I found the MR saying AbstractParam and child classes will be removed, but nothing saying why, and no code showing what would replace the more complicated use-cases like UUIDParam above). I would love to see this improved. Until then, I'm hesitant to upgrade to 2.X.X. Param handling is still confusing in 1.X.X, but at least I won't have to worry about behavior changes.  [1]: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/89712d2346c3a08e9a986a4e256ceff6b37a3cb5/dropwizard-jersey/src/test/java/io/dropwizard/jersey/optional/OptionalQueryParamResourceTest.java#L109

I'm trying to gracefully shutdown my app on TERM signal. So far my code look like: ``` public class ServerApplication extends Application {     public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {                ServerApplication application = new ServerApplication();         application.run(args);          Runtime.getRuntime().addShutdownHook(new Thread("SHUTDOWN_HOOK") {             @Override             public void run() {                 System.out.println("!!! application is shutting down !!!");                 application.delayShutdown();                 application.stop();                 System.out.println("");             }         });     } ```  the `delayShutdown` method will set a boolean to false and sleep for N seconds, i'm doing this in order to make the readiness endpoint of my app fail so that Kubernetes will stop sending traffic to my container.  The code get correctly executed but I've found out that as soon the TERM signal is received Jetty will close the socket and all in new requests will fail and I don't want this, I need for the server to be fully available until the sleep ends.  Running a while true loop with a test curl on TERM will get me: ``` curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 80: Connection refused curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 80: Connection refused curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 80: Connection refused curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 80: Connection refused ```  I've tried shutdownGracePeriod with no luck: ``` server:   shutdownGracePeriod: 90s ```  Would really appreciate the community help on this matter, Thank you!

column3: How to modify/reconfigure Jackson object mapper used for response serialization
column4: I'm trying to add a Jackson FilterProvider to the environment's objectmapper (in @Override run()) ``` environment.getObjectMapper()                 .setFilterProvider(new SimpleFilterProvider()                                            .addFilter(MyFilter.NAME, MyFilter.INSTANCE)); ```  And then I have a Jersey resource that returns type `Response`:  ``` return Response.ok().entity(userCollection).build(); ```  And I get a serialization error: `Cannot resolve PropertyFilter with id 'myFilter'; no FilterProvider configured`  Looking at the code, it seems that the `environment.getObjectMapper()` is passed to `protected Handler createAppServlet(` which calls `jersey.register(new JacksonBinder(objectMapper));` so it seems that this should work.  Relevant dependency versions:  DW: 1.3.4 Jackson: 2.9.5 Jersey: 2.25.1

[2019-12-19T23:10:15,163Z](main)([]) INFO - DiscoverableSubtypeResolver - Unable to load # [2019-12-19T23:10:15,163Z](main)([]) INFO - DiscoverableSubtypeResolver - Unable to load  [2019-12-19T23:10:15,163Z](main)([]) INFO - DiscoverableSubtypeResolver - Unable to load # ```  I could edit the logging on this package/class, but what about filtering the lines of the scanner to only try reading valid class name formats?

column3: Spanner support - invalid properties passed through to Spanner JDBC driver
column4: I'm experimenting with an existing DropWizard application to see how easy it might be to configure it to use Google's Spanner database. I’m running against the Spanner emulator and when I start the application I get an error thrown by the Spanner JDBC driver as follows:  ``` com.google.cloud.spanner.jdbc.JdbcSqlExceptionFactory$JdbcSqlExceptionImpl: INVALID_ARGUMENT: Invalid properties found in connection URI: password, hibernate.dialect, user ```  The Spanner JDBC driver doesn’t like the fact that these properties are being passed down to it and throws an exception. I've checked that the version of Hibernate used by DropWizard 2.0.6 is compatible with the Spanner JDBC library.  Rather than trying to detail the configuration of my application I thought I’d start by asking if Spanner is explicitly supported by DropWizard, and if there are any known issues regardless of if there is explicit support or not.

I'm aware of ticket #1099, but even when using the Grizzly Test Container it fails with:  Test ignored.  java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.util.Objects.requireNonNull(Objects.java:203) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.common.Resource.after(Resource.java:213) 	at io.dropwizard.testing.junit.ResourceTestRule$1.evaluate(ResourceTestRule.java:102) 	at org.junit.rules.RunRules.evaluate(RunRules.java:20) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.run(ParentRunner.java:363) 	at org.junit.runner.JUnitCore.run(JUnitCore.java:137) 	at com.intellij.junit4.JUnit4IdeaTestRunner.startRunnerWithArgs(JUnit4IdeaTestRunner.java:68) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.IdeaTestRunner$Repeater.startRunnerWithArgs(IdeaTestRunner.java:47) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.JUnitStarter.prepareStreamsAndStart(JUnitStarter.java:242) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.JUnitStarter.main(JUnitStarter.java:70)  I've attached a small gradle project to illustrate the issue. I'm trying to test compatibility of the rest of my codebase with JDK 11, so it would be nice if this snapshot was available to help out whilst waiting for the eventual 2.x release.

column3: DropwizardExtensionSupport multiple extensions cannot be ordered
column4: I'd like to be able to set up a stub DropwizardClientExtension to mock an upstream service that my dropwizard app is dependent on. This was possible in junit4 but does not appear possible in junit5.    ```   @Path("/")   public static final class Resource {     @GET     public Response response() {       return Response.ok().build();     }   }   public static final DropwizardClientExtension UPSTREAM = new DropwizardClientExtension(new Resource());    public static final DropwizardAppExtension APP =       new DropwizardAppExtension(           Application.class,           ResourceHelpers.resourceFilePath("configuration.yml"),           ConfigOverride.config("dependentServiceUrl", () -> UPSTREAM.baseUri().toString())); ```  This fails with a NPE: ``` java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.NullPointerException  	at column3: Logging Application Build Version during StartUp
column4: I would like to Log Build Version Number along with the Application Name during the server start up. This can be done in two ways    1. By Reading Implementation-Version property from Manifest file   2. By introducing new file in META-INF(for this to work build plugin needs to be introduced ) to store build info @joschi I would like to know your thoughts on introducing this feature I can work on this feature if everybody interested

I would like to disable the requestLog writing. The `appenders: []` is not working for me, coz I am using spring config server for holding configuration and it fails to parse this line right.  So I found  ```   requestLog:     type: external ```  option. But I wonder if this a right way?

I would like to decorate my logs with some data in MDC that needs to be captured synchronously at the time of logging. Namely - open tracing IDs.   In logback-classic, the user can configure the async appender in XML, so I don't have to do anything special there.  In Dropwizard 1.3, all appenders seem to be async, but the AsyncAppenderFactory doesn't inherit from Discoverable and doesn't appear to be injectable via configuration. In order to use my AsyncAppender, I have to derive from each individual AppenderFactory and override `wrapAsync` to use my AppenderFactory.  I would like to open a PR that would: 1. Make AsyncAppenderFactory inherit from Discoverable 2. Add a configuration parameter under logging that would support setting this (similar to LayoutFactory and AppenderFactory instances today). 3. Use AsyncLoggingEventAppenderFactory by default if not configured  I'm open to: 1. Being wrong; I may have missed something reading the code. 1. Other ways of implementing this; Discoverable seems to be the consistent pattern 2. The name and placement of the config parameter in logging 3. Whether or not this would apply to the request logs (my default is no, since request logs are typically very specific and rarely customized as much). 4. The JsonTypeName applied to the default AsyncLoggingEventAppenderFactory

I want to use the AspectJ library in my dropwizard application.  Actually I want to execute some logic before and after some methods executions of REST resources.  Can I use AspectJ with dropwizard? Is there any reference/documentation available?

I want to intercept entity changes with Hibernate event listeners by adding [Integrators](https://docs.jboss.org/hibernate/orm/5.2/javadocs/org/hibernate/integrator/spi/class-use/Integrator.html) to `BootstrapServiceRegistryBuilder`. BootstrapServiceRegistry is abstracted in [SessionFactoryFactory](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/1024e3c365ff1e3835f62c0a8b643a0835adff03/dropwizard-hibernate/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/hibernate/SessionFactoryFactory.java#L74) and I think a good solution would be to add a protected method to allow its configuration

I understand that most of the development efforts are focused on dropwizard 2.0.0 release -  But, since 1.3.x is the current stable line of versions - I'd appreciate if some dependencies versions in dropwizard-bom can be done and released as dropwizard 1.3.8, where possible. Especially: jetty.version: 9.4.11.v20180605 -> 9.4.14.v20181114 jdbi3.version: 3.2.1 -> 3.5.1  I know that jersey version is more complicated to upgrade and breaks some compatibility, and might fit to be done only in version 2.0.0.

column3: Remove entries covered by the jdbi3-bom
column4: I think these three entries can be removed since we're importing the `jdbi3-bom` above them.

column3: How long will Dropwizard v1 continue to be supported?
column4: I opened another issue (#3335) that I believe is blocking for me to upgrade to Dropwizard 2. After encountering this issue and looking around, I wanted to see if 1.3.X is continuing to receive security updates, etc.  Currently, the migration to v2 seems to be a substantial effort (see #3335), one that I don't have time for at the moment. However, it is important to me that we complete the update before security fixes stop for the 1.3 branch.  In looking at the releases history, it looks like 1.3.27 was released after 2.0 came out, which was great to see. However, I am still curious whether there are clear plans for continuing to provide updates and backports for v1. Is this documented some place that I am missing?  BTW aside from creating a couple of issues recently, I've been really enjoying working with this project. Thank you for all the hard work!

I often use `Duration` and `SizeUnit` for configuration parameters. Because these classes do not implement `java.io.Serializable`, they cause issues when Jackson isn't the serializer. For example, they cause exceptions in Spark jobs when utilized as part of the task (i.e. in a lambda).  I believe that implementing `Serializable` on these classes is low impact, since the interface is purely semantic. Adding a `serialVersionUID ` would be the only other change. Happy to PR this if someone agrees?
I need to know host and port inside Application run method. How do I do that?
I need the marker in my log aggregation stuff. It got added to the 2.x branch at the end of August (#2899). Are you guys ok with backporting to the 1.3.x branch?

column3: Is there a way to show seonds value of timestamp instead of milliseconds in the json format log?
column4: I know dropwizard already support show json format log, i have a config.yml which support output json format log: ```yaml logging:   level: INFO   loggers:     oracle.bi.obis.nccsdropwizard: DEBUG   appenders:     - type: console       layout:         type: json         prettyPrint: false         appendLineSeparator: true         includes: [timestamp, threadName, level, loggerName, message, mdc, exception]         customFieldNames:           timestamp: "time"           message: "msg" #        additionalFields: #          service-name: "user-service"         includesMdcKeys: [userId]         flattenMdc: true         exception:           rootFirst: true           depth: full           evaluators: [org.apache] ``` The output of logs looks like this: ``` {"msg":"Registering jersey handler with root path prefix: /","time":1595580882221,"thread":"main","level":"INFO","logger":"io.dropwizard.server.DefaultServerFactory"} ``` Notice here is unit of the timestamp is milliseconds, i want to make it show the value with seconds, how should I config? Is there an easy way to do so?

I just got distracted by a compiler flag in the parent pom, so I thought I'd file an issue here.  "optimize" is a deprecated compiler flag - [see here](https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/compile-mojo.html#optimize).  ... but it is still used in the parent POM: * https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-parent/pom.xml#L25 * https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-parent/pom.xml#L87

I have noticed a significant performance degradation (> 25%) during the migration to Dropwizard 2.0 both in production and testing due to a newer JDBI version. The upstream issue: https://github.com/jdbi/jdbi/issues/1619

I have a test which relies on DropwizardAppRule.  ``` public class WebServiceTest extends FievelTestBase {   @ClassRule   public static final DropwizardAppRule RULE =       new DropwizardAppRule(           WebService.class,           "./flux/resources/src/main/resources/config/test.yaml");    @Test   public void testBasicServiceHealth() {     String path = WebServiceTest.class.getResource("/config/test.yaml").getPath();     Client client = JerseyClientBuilder.createClient();      Response response =         client             .target(String.format("http://localhost:%d/health", RULE.getLocalPort()))             .request()             .get();      assertEquals(200, response.getStatus());   } } ``` When there is an issue with the server running, all I get from the test is a `NullPointerException` when i call `RULE.getLocalPort()`. Is there a way to print the logs or better visualize the error from this test?  This is dropwizard 1.0.6 so might be fixed in later versions, but just curious anyways.

column3: Dropwiazrd @CacheControl not applying cache control headers
column4: I have a static endpoint in a Dropwizard project that I would like to cache, I've added the `@CacheControl(maxAge = 6, maxAgeUnit = HOURS)` annotation to it. However the response headers have the incorrect header: `Cache-Control: no-cache`.  Debugging with a breakpoint in `CacheControlledResponseFeature`, I can see that the header definitely gets set, but it seems something is overwriting it.  dropwizard version: 2.0.0 jersey version 2.29.1

column3: Multiple static assets with its own routing
column4: I have a react app that I am building and trying to serve using an AssetBundle, as such:  ```     @Override     public void initialize(final Bootstrap bootstrap) {         bootstrap.addBundle(new SwaggerBundle() {             protected SwaggerBundleConfiguration getSwaggerBundleConfiguration(final PersonalWebsiteConfiguration configuration) {                 return configuration.swaggerBundleConfiguration;             }         });         bootstrap.addBundle(new AssetsBundle("/build", "/", "index.html"));     }  ``` I also added the configuration  ``` server:   rootPath: /api ``` so there wouldn't be conflicts with my API.  This works great for just the landing page of my React app. Whenever I try the route /login /dashboard, this page from the UI not found. So I tried adding more bundles to fix that problem with the routing:  ```         bootstrap.addBundle(new AssetsBundle("/build", "/", "index.html"));         bootstrap.addBundle(new AssetsBundle("/build", "/login", "index.html"));         bootstrap.addBundle(new AssetsBundle("/build", "/dashboard", "index.html")); ```  Now, only the dashboard is working. Does anyone know how to serve a React build with multiple routing/pages.

column3: Custom ExceptionMapper mapper is not catching swagger validation
column4: I have a custom exception mapper:  ```java @Provider public class AppExceptionMapper implements ExceptionMapper {     @Context     private HttpServletRequest httpRequest;        @Override     public Response toResponse(final Exception e) {         if (e instanceof ValidationException) {            // return a custom Response here         }          // other mappers     } } ```  And have it registered as `environment.jersey().register(new AppExceptionMapper());`  This would work when in my code I do `throw new ValidationException(...)`. However, I have swagger annotations for validating the request:  ```java @POST public void doSomething(@Valid @NotNull final SomeObject object); ```  When this validation fails, my custom exception mapper does not catch it, and the generic exception is returned. I put a breakpoint inside `ValidationException`, and swagger does throw this exception, but for some reason, my exception mapper is not catching it.  How come?

I have a 1.3.12 application undergoing an exploratory migration to 2.0.0-rc3.  A few working tests are now failing under 2.0.0-rc3.  The tests POST an entity with unknown properties: 1.3.12 returns 400, 2.0.0 returns 204.  If I explicitly configure the objectmapper with objectMapper.configure(DeserializationFeature.FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES, true); then the tests work as they did in 1.3.12.  Explicit configuration seems like "the right thing", but regressions make everyone sad.  ```     // Create an AUTH aware web container with the event resource endpoints available.     @ClassRule     public static final ResourceTestRule eventResource = ResourceTestRule.builder()             .setTestContainerFactory(new GrizzlyWebTestContainerFactory())             .addProvider(new AuthDynamicFeature(                             new OAuthCredentialAuthFilter.Builder()                                     .setAuthenticator(new WebTokenAuthenticator())                                     .setAuthorizer(new WebTokenAuthorizer())                                     .setPrefix("Bearer")                                     .buildAuthFilter()                     )             )             .addProvider(RolesAllowedDynamicFeature.class)             .addProvider(new AuthValueFactoryProvider.Binder(MyUser.class))             .addResource(new EventResource(eventStoreFactory))             .build();      @Before     public void setUp() {     // this fixes the problem in 2.0.0-rc3 eventResource.getObjectMapper().configure(DeserializationFeature.FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES, true);     } ```

I had to change my imports for `AbstractBinder` from `org.glassfish.hk2.utilities.binding` to `org.glassfish.jersey.internal.inject` as was done in 8eb57d0, but could not find anything about this in either the [migration guide](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/wiki/Upgrade-guide-1.3.x-to-2.0.x) or [Jersey's release notes](https://jersey.github.io/release-notes/2.28.html). It's pretty confusing since the old class is still available so there's no compilation errors. I was wondering if Dropwizard has a dependency on something it shouldn't (ie: the old lib) that should be removed to force a compilation error.
I got a notice about https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2018-19362. The solution would be to upgrade Jackson to [2.9.8](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson/wiki/Jackson-Release-2.9.8)

column3: Compilation error in documentation example for Core > Resources
column4: I don't think the code example in the manual that was using a `LongParam` and `IntParam` in the [1.3.x branch here](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/release/1.3.x/docs/source/manual/core.rst#resources), but has been updated to a `OptionalLong` and `OptionalInt` in the [2.0 branch here](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/release/2.0.x/docs/source/manual/core.rst#resources) will compile anymore.  In the `fetch` and `add` methods there are still calls to `userId.get()` and `count.get()` but these are methods that don't exist on the new optional parameter types, only in the previous `LongParam` and `IntParam` types.

column3: Make DropwizardAppExtension work like DropwizardAppRule could
column4: I don't know if this is a Junit issue or DropwizardAppExtension.  https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/2763 correctly explains that DropwizardAppRule with @ClassRule in Junit4 could be used to create one DW container for a suite of integration tests.  I'm currently trying to get this working with DW, Junit5 and gradle and not having much luck.  I keep getting new DW containers for each integration test.  It is desirable to have one DW container for multiple integration tests because of test performance.  Spinning up a container for every test is expensive.  In my case state is not important because all requests are idempotent.  Also, it's best to leave that decision up to each developer.  If clearing state is important then they developer should spin up a new container.  Also, when my app starts up it creates a resource at a known location using a Managed Object.  When the managed object stops the resource is torn down.  If I have 3 concurrent integration tests running, the resource from one test will get torn down before the others have finished.  This causes the other tests to fail.  My app is designed to run as one container, so testing it as multiple containers isn't really testing the real behavior.  Additionally, the resource is expense so my app checks to see if it exists before creating it.  The prevents it from being created if it already exists which might happen if the the tear down fails.    The DropwizardAppRule behavior was great, please bring it back.

column3: Length validation in example doesn't work
column4: I created the simple example app based on the [Getting Started guide](https://www.dropwizard.io/en/stable/getting-started.html), and I run into a problem. The `Saying` class has the `@Length(max = 3)` annotation on its `content` property (see [here](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/ecb4331543d17ee5bbea6e940ee947a33feb3622/dropwizard-example/src/main/java/com/example/helloworld/api/Saying.java#L9)), The guide states  > Lastly, the bean leverages validation to ensure the content size is no greater than 3.  This, to my understanding, should prevent any attempt to assign a string longer than 3 characters to the `content` property.  However, this does not seem to work. For example, when running `curl localhost:8080/hello-world`, the `content` will be `"Hello, Stranger!"` which is clearly longer than 3 characters.   Please let me know if I'm misunderstanding something.

column3: Dropwizard OneOf Validation - doesn't work with nested objects
column4: I am using Dropwizard (version 0.9.2) @OneOf annotation to allow only specific list of values for a field in the entity class.  Below is the resource code `@POST` `@Timed` `@Path("/validation")` `public Response validation(@Valid Map fruits) {`  And Fruit class is as below  `public class Fruit {` `   @OneOf(value = {"apple", "mango", "orange"}, ignoreCase = true)` `    private String name;` `}`  And below is the sample invalid requests data that should return validation failed exception but doesn't.  `{"1": {"123": {"name": "appple"}}}` `{"1": {"123": {"name": "grape"}}}`  FYI, it works fine if the request object is not nested like, however the moment I make the request nested as mentioned above it stops returning the validation failed exception.  Please suggest if I'm missing something here.

https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/issues/3053  ###### Problem: As described in the Issue #3053, the Saying validation annotation doesn't entirely make sense.   ###### Solution: I have removed the ```@Max``` annotation from the ```Saying``` class and removed the ```@Valid``` annotation from the resource. To still show the annotation in use I have modified the ```Person``` class in core and the people resource to reflect that. I have also added a test to show the validation in action on the resource.  ###### Result: I know adding age to a person isn't a particularly sensible thing  to do normally, but it is a good way to show basic use of these annotations in action. Feedback on the test would also be appreciated, without an exception mapper I'm not sure what to test for - other than what I have implemented.

column3: io.dropwizard.Configuration should lazy create server/metrics object
column4: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/master/dropwizard-core/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/Configuration.java#L65  The server/metric object is eager to be created. And this lead to setting up the chain of HTTP connector. If client does not want to use server command, this would result bringing up an HTTP server without actually using it.  I would suggest that we should lazy create this object when we needed to use it.  For example, if client want to create **simple** instead of **default**. And it had to destroy **DefaultServerFactory** object first.

column3: There is no way to shut down the JMXReporter created by Bootstrap
column4: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/ce6348e8aa89bdc63314d7563fbc3062fbb2232c/dropwizard-core/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/setup/Bootstrap.java#L89  The JMXReporter returned on that line isn't saved so there is no way to clean it up. That causes a memory leak when the application is restarted in the same JVM.

column3: Jersey Client Is Created Using Format Itself Instead Of Formatted Name
column4: https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/be1b220cfcc92ac26e0d3b1ca32c2a695d0dbbaf/dropwizard-lifecycle/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/lifecycle/setup/ExecutorServiceBuilder.java#L115  ExecutorServiceManager expects a name, not format. But this line is passing the format itself instead of a name.   JerseyClientBuilder (line 177) passes the format 'jersey-client-[NAME]-%d' to LifecycleEnvironment, which passes that format to this class as part of constructor. This class then takes the format, but does no formatting using it, rather just passes it wrongfully to ExecutorServiceManager.  Not sure what's the intent of that '%d' is. So can't really provide a pull request for it. Someone familiar with these code need to fix it.  Effect of this is, metric is getting generated with that %d in the name.  Same is occurring with TimeBoundHealthCheck pool also. I haven't yet traced the code responsible for it. It'll be nice to get that fixed too.

Hi,  It appears that the [dropwizard-scala](https://github.com/datasift/dropwizard-scala) library that our company relies on, is not going to be upgraded to support 2.0. So this means that we will not be able to use Dropwizard with Scala going forward, unless we maintain that library ourselves or create a new one. Is there any plan from the Dropwizard team to offer native Scala support? Is Dropwizard+Scala a popular combination? Thanks!

column3: Support for setting SameSite attribute on HttpSession JSESSIONID cookie
column4: Hi,  A Chrome update will cause the SameSite cookie attribute to be set to lax be default, if it is not set. I need to set the value to "None", but as far as I can see, the SameSite attribute cannot currently be set via e.g. javax.servlet.SessionCookieConfig.  C.f. https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/4247 Jetty is enabled from version 9.4.27 to handle configuration of the SameSite attribute, but the latest dropwizard version uses 9.4.25.  When version 9.4.27 is used, I believe the attribute can be set via: environment.getApplicationContext().getServletContext().setAttribute(HttpCookie.SAME_SITE_DEFAULT_ATTRIBUTE, "NONE");  Thanks, -Louise

column3: Unable to test configuration file with parameter
column4: Hi there. I'm trying to test a dropwizard configuration file following the guidelines set out here: https://www.dropwizard.io/1.3.13/docs/manual/testing.html#testing-configurations  This works fine for simple configuration files, but unfortunately doesn't cater for more complex configuration files involving parameters.  For example, the following configuration will fail to parse:  Config file: ```java import io.dropwizard.Configuration; import lombok.Getter;  @Getter public class SomeConfigurationFile extends Configuration {     private long someAttribute; } ```  YAML file: ```yaml server:   applicationConnectors:     - type: http       port: 1234    adminConnectors:     - type: http       port: 5678  someAttribute: ${SOME_ENV_VAR:-3000} ```  When attempting to run this, i get the following error:  ```log io.dropwizard.configuration.ConfigurationParsingException: src/main/resources/config.yaml has an error:   * Incorrect type of value at: pollingFrequency; is of type: String, expected: long  	at io.dropwizard.configuration.ConfigurationParsingException$Builder.build(ConfigurationParsingException.java:279) 	at io.dropwizard.configuration.BaseConfigurationFactory.build(BaseConfigurationFactory.java:149) 	at io.dropwizard.configuration.BaseConfigurationFactory.build(BaseConfigurationFactory.java:89) 	at io.dropwizard.configuration.ConfigurationFactory.build(ConfigurationFactory.java:28) 	at .(.java:44) 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) 	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) 	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498) 	at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod$1.runReflectiveCall(FrameworkMethod.java:50) 	at org.junit.internal.runners.model.ReflectiveCallable.run(ReflectiveCallable.java:12) 	at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod.invokeExplosively(FrameworkMethod.java:47) 	at org.junit.internal.runners.statements.InvokeMethod.evaluate(InvokeMethod.java:17) 	at org.junit.internal.runners.statements.RunBefores.evaluate(RunBefores.java:26) 	at org.junit.contrib.java.lang.system.EnvironmentVariables$EnvironmentVariablesStatement.evaluate(EnvironmentVariables.java:122) 	at org.junit.rules.RunRules.evaluate(RunRules.java:20) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runLeaf(ParentRunner.java:325) 	at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:78) 	at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:57) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$3.run(ParentRunner.java:290) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$1.schedule(ParentRunner.java:71) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runChildren(ParentRunner.java:288) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.access$000(ParentRunner.java:58) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner$2.evaluate(ParentRunner.java:268) 	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.run(ParentRunner.java:363) 	at org.junit.runner.JUnitCore.run(JUnitCore.java:137) 	at com.intellij.junit4.JUnit4IdeaTestRunner.startRunnerWithArgs(JUnit4IdeaTestRunner.java:68) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.IdeaTestRunner$Repeater.startRunnerWithArgs(IdeaTestRunner.java:47) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.JUnitStarter.prepareStreamsAndStart(JUnitStarter.java:242) 	at com.intellij.rt.execution.junit.JUnitStarter.main(JUnitStarter.java:70) Caused by: com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidFormatException: Cannot deserialize value of type `long` from String "${someAttribute:-3000}": not a valid Long value  at [Source: UNKNOWN; line: -1, column: -1] (through reference chain: ["someAttribute"]) 	at com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidFormatException.from(InvalidFormatException.java:67) 	at com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.DeserializationContext.weirdStringException(DeserializationContext.java:1549) ```  The reason for this is that i have no way to define a ConfigurationSourceProvider within this test. When running the full application, i can initialise this using the Application.initialize() method as follows:  ```java bootstrap.setConfigurationSourceProvider(     new SubstitutingSourceProvider(         bootstrap.getConfigurationSourceProvider(),         new EnvironmentVariableSubstitutor(false)) ); ```  This is not available in the test however. Does anyone know how this could be achieved?  My test class:  ```java import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper; import io.dropwizard.configuration.EnvironmentVariableSubstitutor; import io.dropwizard.configuration.SubstitutingSourceProvider; import io.dropwizard.configuration.YamlConfigurationFactory; import io.dropwizard.jackson.Jackson; import io.dropwizard.jersey.validation.Validators; import io.dropwizard.setup.Bootstrap; import io.dropwizard.testing.ResourceHelpers; import io.dropwizard.testing.junit.DropwizardAppRule; import org.junit.Before; import org.junit.ClassRule; import org.junit.Rule; import org.junit.Test;  import javax.validation.Validator; import java.io.File;  import static org.junit.Assert.*;  public class MyConfigurationTest {      private YamlConfigurationFactory factory;      @Before     public void setUp() {         ObjectMapper objectMapper = Jackson.newObjectMapper();         Validator validator = Validators.newValidator();         factory = new YamlConfigurationFactory(MyConfiguration.class, validator, objectMapper, "dw");     }      @Test     public void testAppConfigurationIsValid() throws Exception {         File yaml = new File("src/main/resources/config.yaml");         final MyConfiguration config = factory.build(yaml);         assertNotNull(config);     } } ```

column3: how to configure for higher connectivity?
column4: Hi there,  I am using **sudo java -jar  server ** to run application, but when it's tested by jmeter for >5000 connections/second, error occurs:  ``` WARN  [2019-10-22 06:46:56,366] org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.EatWhatYouKill:  ! java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException: CEP:SocketChannelEndPoint@604074b3{/172.31.39.117:49742/172.31.37.35:80,OPEN,fill=FI,flush=-,to=722/30000}{io=1/0,kio=1,kro=1}->HttpConnection@175ced0e[p=HttpParser{s=START,0 of -1},g=HttpGenerator@30df28da{s=START}]=>HttpChannelOverHttp@754ef495{r=0,c=false,a=IDLE,uri=null,age=0}:runFillable:BLOCKING ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool.execute(QueuedThreadPool.java:440) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.EatWhatYouKill.execute(EatWhatYouKill.java:370) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.EatWhatYouKill.doProduce(EatWhatYouKill.java:305) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.EatWhatYouKill.tryProduce(EatWhatYouKill.java:168) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.strategy.EatWhatYouKill.run(EatWhatYouKill.java:126) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.ReservedThreadExecutor$ReservedThread.run(ReservedThreadExecutor.java:366) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool.runJob(QueuedThreadPool.java:765) ! at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool$2.run(QueuedThreadPool.java:683) ! at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:835) ```  Behind my REST api a thread pool (thread count=50, queue size=100) is designated to process requests, I tried to enlarge these numbers, but failed to see a better performance.  Would you help recommend a better configuration for higher connectivity? or what items should be tuned like the **java parameters** / **thread pool size/queue size** / **dropwizard yml configuration items**? Thank you very much for any help.

column3: Implementing extended ExceptionMapper interface generates javax.ws.rs.ProcessingException
column4: Hi team. I created an interface that extends **ExceptionMapper** to introduce additional behaviour.   **Context:** Using Dropwizard-Jersey:1.3.7   ``` public interface DetailedExceptionMapper extends ExceptionMapper {      String getDetailedMessage(T t); } ```   In my custom exception mappers I try to implement the above interface like this  ``` public class ConstraintViolationExceptionMapper implements DetailedExceptionMapper {      @Override     public String getDetailedMessage(ConstraintViolationException ex) {}      @Override     public Response toResponse(ConstraintViolationException ex) {} } ```  I then bind the custom exception mapper to Jersey.  ``` public void run(){   environment.jersey().register(new ConstraintViolationExceptionMapper());   ... }  ```  When I try to run the app, it produces the following stacktrace:  ``` javax.servlet.ServletException: io.dropwizard.jersey.setup.JerseyServletContainer-6ee5f485@cb19b188==io.dropwizard.jersey.setup.JerseyServletContainer,jsp=null,order=1,inst=false Caused by: A MultiException has 2 exceptions.  They are: 1. javax.ws.rs.ProcessingException: Could not find exception type for given ExceptionMapper class: class com.flipkart.m3.selfserve.app.exception.mapper.ConstraintViolationExceptionMapper. 2. javax.servlet.GenericServlet.init(GenericServlet.java:244) 	at org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletHolder.initServlet(ServletHolder.java:670) 	... 41 more Caused by: javax.ws.rs.ProcessingException: Could not find exception type for given ExceptionMapper class: class com.flipkart.m3.selfserve.app.exception.mapper.ConstraintViolationExceptionMapper. 	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.ExceptionMapperFactory.getType(ExceptionMapperFactory.java:263) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.ExceptionMapperFactory.getExceptionType(ExceptionMapperFactory.java:233) 	at org.glassfish.jersey.internal.ExceptionMapperFactory.(ExceptionMapperFactory.java:209) 	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method) 	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62) 	at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45) fine.  ``` public class ConstraintViolationExceptionMapper implements DetailedExceptionMapper, ExceptionMapper {  public interface DetailedExceptionMapper{      String getDetailedMessage(T t); }  ```  Other exception mappers that directly implement ExceptionMapper work fine. I think that because of Generic type erasure, ExceptionMapper doesn't get passed to the extended interface. But I might be wrong.

column3: Release of 2.x because of Jetty CVE-2020-27216
column4: Hi Dropwizard team!  We'd like to update Jetty to 9.4.33 due to the aforementioned vulnerability. Could you also please make a release of the current master branch?  The issue was fixed in #3546.  Thanks!  Christopher

column3: Connection resets under highly concurrent traffic
column4: Hi All,  I'm using Apache Bench [1] to push some load through a vanilla dropwizard application. I'm hitting the admin ping resource with around 250 concurrent connections for a duration of about 30 seconds [2]. During these tests I see "connection resets" [3]. This test is NOT using keep-alive and so every request is creating a new TCP socket.   With keep-alives turned on the tests pass with flying colours.   Is there any advice / guidance as to the max number new of connections  / second? And / or is there some configuration settings that I can I tweak to set / discover this limit. I've tried `maxThreads ` with no success.  Thanks for any advice.   [1] https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/programs/ab.html [2] ab -c 250 -t 30 -n 10000000 http://localhost:8081/admin/ping [3] `This is ApacheBench, Version 2.3  Copyright 1996 Adam Twiss, Zeus Technology Ltd, http://www.zeustech.net/ Licensed to The Apache Software Foundation, http://www.apache.org/  Benchmarking localhost (be patient) apr_socket_recv: Connection reset by peer (54) Total of 14514 requests completed`

Also in the "Usage" part it is really unclear how to create a "database" object.  Please provide some more words in the documentation how to create such objects.

Hi after last update of 1.3 my app fail to run. After small investigation I've found the dropwizard-bom don't use jetty bom https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/tree/jetty-9.4.x/jetty-bom which will store all versions which is needed for jetty related artifacts  I don't have chance to look at DW 2.0, so maybe the same issue exists there

Hey, I realized that shade maven plugin won't include test classes so if build a fat jar i can't run unit tests in that build.  I've google a lot but I don't find a way to build a fat jar and run my tests in the same build. Is there another way to do it?

column3: @Auth does not bind on resource fields (Dropwizard 2.0.12)
column4: Hey,  I'm upgrading from Dropwizard 1.3.14 to 2.0.12 and found that a field in a resource annotated with `@Auth` does not get a Principal binded anymore. So this example previously worked but does not anymore: ```java @Produces(MediaType.TEXT_HTML) @Path(/roles) public class Resource {  	@Auth 	private User user;  	@GET 	public View getRoles() { 		// user is null here 	} } ```  I guess its because of Jersey's `AbstractValueParamProvider` only scans method parameters but not class fields of a resource. The `@Auth` annotation however still allows to be placed on fields.
