column3: Support the simple: „Ignore unrecognized arguments“ use case | aka: Support executing Java 9+ Module applications
column4: ### Proposed Support  Please refactor *Dropwizard* to support executing a main class in a JPMS module by implementing the simple ability to ignore unrecognized arguments? An *argparse4j* contributor [*offered this as a basis*](https://github.com/argparse4j/argparse4j/issues/46#issuecomment-122288220) for this proposed ability.  ### Context  Several new command line options were introduced to the Java Development Kit to support Java 9's Jigsaw feature. Two of those are the *`--module-path`* and the *`-m`* switches. Used together, they make it possible to execute a *`Main-Class`* of a Java application exposed by a Jigsaw module.  [*This is the `java` tool's description*](http://bit.ly/JavaRefrnc) of the usage of those options:  ``` $java --help Usage: java [options]  [args...]            (to execute a class)    ...    or  java [options] -m [/] [args...]        java [options] --module [/] [args...]            (to execute the main class in a module)    ...  Arguments following the main class, source file, -jar ,  -m or --module / are passed as the arguments to  main class. ```   ### The Problem  Popular Java build tools append the following „*immutable system properties*“ to the end of every Java command that application developers explicitly specify:  ``` ...-Dfile.encoding=x-mac-roman -Duser.country=FR -Duser.language=fr -Duser.variant  ```  For example, consider the following *Dropwizard* application command line that would be produced by a build tool:   ``` java --module-path build/libs/my.dropwizard.module.jar -m my.dropwizard.module/io.my.DropwizardApp db status my_dropwizard_app.yml -Dfile.encoding=x-mac-roman -Duser.country=FR -Duser.language=fr -Duser.variant ```  *Dropwizard* uses *argparse4j* to implement its underlying CLI feature. The above „*`db status`*“ arguments are legal *Dropwizard* arguments. However, the „*`-D...`*“ system properties — *appended to the command by the build tool* — cause *Dropwizard* to fail to execute the application. Through *argparse4j*, *Dropwizard* reports an „*`unrecognized arguments: -Dfile.encoding...`*“ error to *`stderr`*:  ``` ... [ERROR] [system.err] unrecognized arguments: '-Dfile.encoding=x-mac-roman' [ERROR] [system.err] usage: java -jar authentication-application.jar [ERROR] [system.err]        db status [-h] [--migrations MIGRATIONS-FILE] [ERROR] [system.err]        [--catalog CATALOG] [--schema SCHEMA] [-v] [-i CONTEXTS] [file] [ERROR] [system.err] [ERROR] [system.err] Check for pending change sets. [ERROR] [system.err] [ERROR] [system.err] positional arguments: [ERROR] [system.err]   file                   application configuration file [ERROR] [system.err] [ERROR] [system.err] optional arguments: [ERROR] [system.err]   -h, --help             show this help message and exit ... ```  The combination of three popular Java technologies (*Dropwizard*, *argparse4j*, *Gradle*) makes it practically impossible to use a modern JDK's *`--module-path`* and *`-m`* options. When those three are used together they break any JPMS-architected application that needs to execute an application in a module. That is because the implementation details of each one, combines with the other two, to produce a situation that does not comply with the JPMS specification.  ### Steps to Reproduce  1. Clone or download [*this project*](https://bit.ly/mrJarZard) 2. Follow the setup instructions in that project's *`README`*, to configure and run the *Dropwizard* application 3. In the *`build.gradle`* located in the project's root directory, find the *`mrjar{}`* block of the *`project('authentication-application'`*) section of the script (*[go to line 96](http://bit.ly/mrJarWizL96)*) 4. Edit the *`mrjar`* block to be this:      ```     mrjar{         main = 'com.alexkudlick.authentication.application.AuthenticationApplication'         isModular = true         moduleName = 'com.alexkudlick.authentication.application'     }      ``` 5. Open a terminal in the root directory of the project 6. Enter *`./gradlew -i -Dconsole=verbose --debug authentication-application:run`* 7. Observe the *`[ERROR] [system.err] unrecognized arguments: '-Dfile.encoding=windows-1252'`* failure message   ### Expected Behavior  Just like the *Dropwizard/argparse4j* project in *Steps To Reproduce* section above, [*this other demo project*](http://bit.ly/mrJarularity) likewise implements a JPMS module that can be executed from the command. It, likewise, is built and ran using the *Gradle* build tool. However, the differences are     * the latter is not implemented with *Dropwizard/argparse4j*  * the later, therefore, ***is*** compliant with the *`java`* tool's expectations for executing a main class in a module  * its [*`mrjar{}` configuration*](http://bit.ly/etSvcsL37) has an *`isModular = true`* property     That is to say: *Unlike the Dropwizard/argparse4j project, the other project Just Works because it — as expected — simply ignores any command line arguments passed to it that it's not interested in*.  ### What Have You Tried So Far?  I have raised similar requests with both [*the argparse4j project*](https://github.com/argparse4j/argparse4j/issues/121) and [*the Gradle project*](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/10825) .  TIA :+1:

### Problem: In our application we want to have a custom application specific locale detection procedure based on query parameters of the HTTP request. Currently, the `ViewMessageBodyWriter.detectLocale` method is package private which makes it quite cumbersome to override.  ### Solution: Make `ViewMessageBodyWriter.detectLocale` protected  ### Result: We will be able to register our own ViewMessageBodyWriter implementation which overrides the `detectLocale` method in a nice way.

column3: Consider enabling HTTP client connection validation by default
column4: # Why  dropwizard-client currently disables HTTP client detection for half-closed TCP connections [by default](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/blob/de7581fabd358853e2853b80235a491c50443e0f/dropwizard-client/src/main/java/io/dropwizard/client/HttpClientConfiguration.java#L59-L60) ([PR which added this behavior](https://github.com/dropwizard/dropwizard/pull/1181)). This can cause quite some surprises when enabling the `keepalive` option. Without this HTTP clients may attempt to issue HTTP requests via half-closed TCP connections resulting in either `SocketException`s or `NoHttpResponseException`s.  The following screenshot shows a DW server app sending a FIN/ACK to a DW client. The client established a TCP connection to the server via Apache HTTP client. Notice how the client ignores this and instead tries to reuse the TCP connection for a follow up HTTP request.  ![image (2)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/596443/90731864-8ae8b880-e2ca-11ea-8372-33eadf592a10.png)  One could interpret this as a misbehavior within Apache HTTP client. However this behavior [is documented](https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-4.5.x/tutorial/html/connmgmt.html) (search for "stale" in the doc). Furthermore Apache HTTP client [by default](https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-client/blob/bd3be1b86dc279cd5b55ec7a9c248578e9315328/httpclient/src/main/java/org/apache/http/impl/conn/PoolingHttpClientConnectionManager.java#L183) executes checks for half-closed/stale connections. Unfortunately though the Dropwizard default overwrites this to *disabled by default*.   # What  I'd propose to enable this check by default and to use the default value visible within Apache HTTP client. Seems like they revised the default [at least once](https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-client/commit/6e6b8e5180e94da14efd60f4735416b9b873ae4b) so it seems like a sensible value to me.

column3: Fix date formatting pattern in test
column4: "Y" is actually the year according to "week of year"-based calendars. This will be different from the calendar year on dates like 2018-12-30, which has a "y" of 2018 and a "Y" of 2019.  http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/tr35-10.html#Date_Format_Patterns
